editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Why do you grieve thus still?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Twould melt a marble
And tame a savage man, to feel my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: What fortune? I have lived this 30. years
And run through all these follies you call fortunes
Yet never fixed on any good, and constant,
But what I made myself: why should I grieve then,
And that I may mould any way?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are wide still.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You love a gentlewoman, a young handsome woman,
I have loved a thousand, not so few.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are disposed.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You hope to marry her; 'tis a lawful calling
And prettily esteemed of, but take heed then,
Take heed dear brother of a stranger fortune
Then ere you felt yet; fortune my foe is a friend to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis true I love, dear, and truly love,
A noble, virtuous, and most beauteous maid,
And am beloved again.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's too much a conscience
To love all these would run me out o my wits.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Prithee give ear, I am to marry her

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Dispatch it then, and I'll go call the piper.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But o the wicked customs of this country
The barbarous, most inhumane, damned custom

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis true, to marry is a custom
In the world; for look you brother,
Wooed any man, stand plucking for the ace of hearts,
With one pack of cards all days on's life?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You do not
Or else you purpose not to understand me

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Proceed, I will give care.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: They have a custom
In this most beastly country, out upon't.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let's hear it first.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That when a maid is contracted
And ready for the tie o'th church, the governor,
He that commands in chief, must have her maidenhead
Or ransom it for money at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How might a man achieve that place? A rare custom?
An admirable rare custom: and none excepted?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: None, none.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The rarer still: how could I lay about me?
In this rare office? are they born to it, or chosen?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Both equal damnable.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Methinks both excellent
Would I were the next heir

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To this mad fortune
Am I now come, my marriage is proclaimed.
And nothing can redeem me from this mischief,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: She's very young;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And fair I dare proclaim her
Else mine eyes fail,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fair as the bud unblasted.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I cannot blame him then if 'twere mine own case.
I would not go an ace less

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fie Rutillio
Why do you make your brother's misery
Your sport and game?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There is no pastime like it

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I looked for your advice, your timely counsel,
How to avoid this blow, not to be mocked at,
And my afflictions jeered.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I tell thee Arnoldo,
An thou wert my father, as thou art but my brother,
My younger brother too, I must be merry
And where there is a wench it can, a young wench,
A handsome wench, and sooner a good turn too,
An I were to be hanged, thus must I handle it.
But you shall see sir, I can change this habit
To do you any service; advise what you please,
And see with what devotion I'll attend it?
But yet methinks , I am taken with this custom.
And could pretend to'th place.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Draw off a little?
Here comes my mistress and her father.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Jam dainty wench;
Wooed might farm his custom

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My dear daughter,
Now to bethink yourself of new advice
Will be too late, later this timeless sorrow,
No price, nor prayers, can infringe the fate
Your beauty hath cast on you, my best Zenocia,
Be ruled by me, a father's care directs ye,
Look on the count, look cheerfully and sweetly;
What though he have the power to possess ye,
To pluck your maiden honour, and then slight ye
By custom, unresistable to enjoy you;
Yet my sweet child, so much your youth and goodness
The beauty of your soul, and saintlike modesty,
Have won upon his wild mind, so much charmed
That all power laid aside, what law allows him,
Or sudden in fires, kindled from those bright eyes,
He sues to be your servant, fairly, nobly
Forever to be tied your faithful husband:
Consider my best child:

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I have considered

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The blessedness that this breeds too, consider
Besides your father's honour, your own peace,
The banishment for ever of this custom
This base and barbarous use, for after once
He has found the happiness of holy marriage
And what it is to grow up with one beauty,
How he will scorn and kick at such a heritage
Left him by lust and lewd progenitors.
All virgins too, shall bless your name, shall saint it,
And like so many pilgrims go to your shrine,
When time has turned your beauty into ashes,
Filled with your pious memory.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Good father
Hide not that bitter pill, I loathe to swallow
In such sweet words:

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The count's a handsome gentleman,
And having him, you're certain of a fortune,
A high and noble fortune to attend you:
Where if you fling your love upon this stranger
This young Arnoldo, not knowing from what place
Or honourable strain of blood he is sprung, you venture
All your own sweets, and my long cares to nothing,
Nor are you certain of his faith; why may not that
Wander as he does, everywhere ?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: No more sir;
I must not hear, I dare not hear him wronged thus,
Virtue is never wounded, but I suffer.
'Tis an ill office in your age, a poor one,
To judge thus weakly: and believe yourself too,
A weaker to betray your innocent daughter,
To his intemperate, rude, and wild embraces,
She hates as heaven hates falsehood.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A good wench,
She sticks close to you sir.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: His faith uncertain?
The nobleness his virtue springs from, doubted?
D'ye doubt 'tis day now? or when your body's perfect,
Your stomachs well disposed, your pulses temperate,
D'ye doubt you are in health? I tell you father,
One hour of this man's goodness, this man's nobleness
Put in the scale, against the counts whole being,
Forgive his lusts too, which are half his life,
He could no more endure to hold weight with him;
Arnoldo's very looks, are fair examples;
His common and indifferent actions,
Rules and strong ties of virtue: he has my first love,
To him in sacred vow I have given this body,
In him my mind inhabits.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good wench still

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And till he fling me off, as undeserving
Which I confess I am, of such a blessing,
But would be loath to find it so —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O never;
Never my happy mistress, never, never,
When your poor servant lives but in your favour,
One foot it'h grave, the other shall not linger,
What sacrifice of thanks, what age of service,
What danger, of more dreadful look then death,
What willing martyrdom to crown me constant
May merit such a goodness, such a sweetness?
A love so nobly great, no power can ruin;
Most blessed maid go on, the gods that gave this,
This pure unspotted love, the child of heaven,
In their own goodness, must preserve and save it
And raise you a reward, beyond our recompense;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I ask but you, a pure maid to possess,
And then they have crowned my wishes: if I fall then
Go seek some better love, mine will debase you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A pretty innocent fool; well governor,
Though I think well of your custom, and could wish myself
For this night in your place, heartily wish it:
Yet if you play not fair play, and above board too,
I have a foolish gin here, I say no more;
I'll tell you what and if your honour's guts are not enchanted

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I should now chide you sir, for so declining
The goodness and the grace you have ever showed me,
And your own virtue too, in seeking rashly
To violate that love heaven has appointed,
To wrest your daughter's thoughts, part that affection
That both our hearts have tied and seek to give it,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To a wild fellow, that would weary her;
A cannibal, that feeds on the heads of maids,
Then flings their bones and bodies to the devil,
Would any man of discretion venture such a gristle,
To the rude claws of such a catamountain?
You had better tear her between oaks, a town bull
Is a mere Stoic to this fellow, a grave philosopher,
And a Spanish jennet, a most virtuous gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Does this seem handsome sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Though I confess
Any man would desire to have her, and by any means,
At any rate too, yet that this common hangman,
That hath whipped off the heads of a 1000. maids already
That he should glean the harvest, sticks in my stomach:
This rogue that breaks young wenches to the saddle,
And teaches them to stumble ever after;
That he should have her? for my brother now
That is a handsome young fellow; and well thought on,
And will deal tenderly in the business;
Or for myself that have a reputation,
And have studied the conclusions of these causes
And know the perfect manage, I'll tell you old sir,
If I should call you wise sir, I should bely you,
This thing you study to betray your child to.
This maiden-monger. When you have done your best
And think you have fixed her in the point of honour
Who do you think you have tied her too? A surgeon,
I must confess an excellent dissector,
One that has cut up more young tender lamb-pies —

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What I speak gentlemen, was mere compulsion
No father's freewill, nor did I touch your person,
With any edge of spite; or strain your loves
With any base, or hired persuasions;Exit.
Witness these tears, how well I wished your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There's some grace in thee yet, you are determined,
To marry this count lady,

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Marry him Rutillio?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Marry him, and lie with him I mean,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: You cannot mean that,
If you be a true gentleman, you dare not,
The brother to this man, and one that loves him;
I'll marry the devil first

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A better choice
And lay his horns by a handsomer bedfellow,
A cooler of my conscience

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray let me ask you;
And my dear mistress, be not angry with me
For what I shall propound, I am confident,
No promise, nor no power, can force your love,
I mean in way of marriage, never stir you,
Nor to forget my faith, no state can wound you.
But for this custom, which this wretched country
Hath wrought into a law, and must be satisfied;
Where all the pleas of honour, are but laughed at,
And modesty regarded as a may-game,
What shall be here considered? power we have none,
To make resistance, nor policy to cross it:
'Tis held religion too, to pay this duty.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I'll die an atheist then.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My noblest mistress
Not that I with it so, but say it were so,
Say you did render up, part of your honour,
For whilst your will is clear, all cannot perish;
Say for one night, you entertained this monster
Should I esteem you worse, forced to this render?
Your mind I know is pure, and full as beauteous;
After this short eclipse, you would rise again
And shaking of that cloud, spread all your lustre

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Who made you witty, to undo yourself, sir?
Or are you laden, with the love I bring you,
And fain would fling that burden on another?
Am I grown common in your eyes Arnoldo?
Old, or unworthy of your fellowship?
D'ye think because a woman, I must err,
And therefore rather wish that fall before hand
Coloured with custom, not to be resisted?
D'ye love as painters do, only some pieces
Some certain handsome touches of your mistress,
And let the mind pass by you, unexamined?
Be not abused; with what the maiden vessel
Is seasoned first, you understand the proverb.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am afraid, this thing will make me virtuous,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Should you lay by the least part of that love
You've sworn is mine, your youth and faith has given me,
To entertain another, nay a fairer,
And make the case thus desperate, she must die else;
D'ye think I would give way, or count this honest?
Be not deceived, these eyes should never see you more,
This tongue forget to name you, and this heart
Hate you, as if you were born, my full antipathy.
Empire and more imperious love, alone
Rule, and admit no rivals, the purest springs
When they are courted by lascivious land-floods,
Their maiden pureness, and their coolness perish.
And though they purge again to their first beauty,
The sweetness of their taste, is clean departed.
I must have all or none; and am not worthy
Longer the noble name of wife, Arnoldo,
Than I can bring a whole heart pure and handsome.

sp.speaker: Arnol.
sp.l: I never shall deserve you: not to thank you;
You are so heavenly good, no man can reach you:
I am sorry I spoke so rashly, was but to try you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You might have tried a thousand women so,
And 900, fourscore and 19 should ha' followed your counsel
Take heed of clapping spurs to such free cattle,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: We must bethink us suddenly and constantly,
And wisely too, we expect no common danger.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Be most assured, I'll die first.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: An't come to that once,
The devil pick his bones, that dies a coward
I'll jog along with you, here comes the stallion
How smug he looks upon the imagination
Of what he hopes to act? pox on your kidneys,
How they begin to melt? how big he bears
Sure he will leap before us all: what a sweet company
Of rogues and panders, wait upon his lewdness?
Plague of your chops, you ha' more handsome bits,
Than a hundred honester men, and more deserving
How the dog leers.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You need not now be jealous
I speak at distance to your wife, but when the priest has done
We shall grow nearer, and more familiar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'll watch you for that trick, baboon, I'll
Smoke you: the rogue sweats, as if he had eaten
Grains, he broils, if I do come to the
Basting of you.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Your lordship.
May happily speak this, to fright a stranger,
But 'tis not in your honour, to perform it;
The custom of this place, if such there be,
At best most damnable, may urge you to it,
But if you be an honest man you hate it,
However I will presently prepare
To make her mine, and most undoubtedly;
Believe you are abused, this custom feigned to,
And what you now pretend, most fair and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Go and believe, a good belief does well sir;
And you sir, clear the place, but leave her here.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your lordship's pleasure

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: That anon Arnoldo,
This is but talk

sp.speaker: Rut
sp.l: Shall we go off?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By any means
I know she has pious thoughts enough to guard her:
Besides, here's nothing due to him till the tie be done
Nor dare he offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now do I long to worry him:
Pray have a care to the main chance. Ex. Arn. and Rut.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Pray sir fear not

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now, what say you to me?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Sir it becomes
The modesty, that maids are ever born with,
To use few words.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Do you see nothing in me
Nothing to catch your eyes nothing of wonder,
The common mould of men, come short, and want in?
Do you read no future fortune for yourself here?
And what a happiness, it may be to you,
To have him honour you, all women aim at?
To have him love you lady, that man love you,
The best, and the most beauteous, have run mad for?
Look and be wise, you have a favour offered you
I do not every day propound to women;
You are a pretty one: and though each hour,
I am glutted, with the sacrifice of beauty,
I may be brought, as you may handle it,
To cast so good a grace and liking on you,
You understand, come kiss me, and be joyful,
I give you leave.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Faith sir, 'twill not show handsome;
Our sex his blushing, full of fear, unskilled too,
In these alarms.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Learn then and be perfect

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I do beseech your honour pardon me,
And take some skilful one, can hold you play,
I am a fool.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I tell thee maid I love thee,
Let that word make thee happy, so far love thee,
That though I may enjoy thee without ceremony,
I will descend so low, to marry thee,
Methinks I see the race, that shall spring from us,
Some princes, some great soldiers

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I am afraid.
Your honours cozened in this calculation;
For certain, I shall ne'er have a child by you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Because I must not think to marry you,
I dare not sir, the step betwixt your honour,
And my poor humble state.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I will descend to thee,
And buoy thee up.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'll sink to th' centre first,
Why would your lordship marry, and confine that pleasure,
You ever have had freely cast upon you?
Take heed my lord this marring is a mad matter,
Lighter a pair of shackles will hang on you,
And quieter a quartain fever find you
If you wed me I must enjoy you only,
Your eyes must be called home, your thoughts in cages,
To sing to no ears then but mine; your heart bound
The custom, that your youth was ever nursed in,
Must be forgotten, I shall forget my duty else,
And how that will appear,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: We'll talk of that more

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Besides I tell ye, I am naturally,
As all young women are, that show like handsome,
Exceeding proud, being commended, monstrous. Boy ready for the songs
Of an unquiet temper, seldom pleased.
Unless it be with infinite observance.
Which you were never bred to; once well angered,
As every cross in us, provokes that passion,
And like a sea, I roll, toss, and chase a week after.
And then all mischief I can think upon,
Abusing of your bed the least and poorest,
I tell you what you'll find, and in these fits,
This little beauty, you are pleased to honour,
Will be so changed, so altered to an ugliness,
To such a vizard, ten to one, I die too,
Take't then upon my death you murdered me,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away, away fool, why dost thou proclaim these
To prevent that in me, thou hast chosen in another

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Him I have chosen, I can rule and master,
Temper to what I please, you are a great one
Of a strong will to bend, I dare not venture,
Be wise my lord, and say you were well counselled,
Take money for my ransom, and forget me,
'Twill be both safe, and noble for your honour,
And wheresoever my fortunes shall conduct me,
So worthy mentions I shall render of you
So virtuous and so fair.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You will not marry me:

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I do beseech your honour, be not angry
At what I say, I cannot love ye, dare not;
But such a ransom, for the flower you covet

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: No money, nor no prayers, shall redeem that,
Not all the art you have

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Set your own price sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Go to your wedding, never kneel to me
When that's done, you are mine, I will enjoy you:
Your tears do nothing, I will not lose my custom
To cast upon myself an empire's fortuneExit.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: My mind shall not pay this custom, cruel man

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Your body will content me: I'll look for you,Ex.

div.stage: Enter Charino and servants in blacks. Covering the place with blacks.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Strew all your withered flowers, your autumn sweets
By the hot sun ravished of bud and beauty
Thus round about her bridebed hang those blacks there
The emblems of her honour lost; all joyBowl of wine ready.
That leads a virgin to receive her lover,
Keep from this place all fellow-maids that bless her,
And blushing and unloose her zone, keep from her:
No merry noise nor lusty songs be heard here,
Nor full cups crowned with wine, make the rooms giddy;
This is no mask of mirth, but murdered honour.
Sing mournfully that sad epithalamion,
I gave thee now: and prithee let thy lute weep.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now, what livery's this? do you call this a wedding?
This is more like a funeral.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It is one,
And my poor daughter going to her grave,
To his most loathed embraces that gapes for her.
Make the Earls bed ready, is the marriage done sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes they are knit; but must this slubberdegullion
Have her maidenhead now?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: There's no avoiding it?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And there's the scaffold where she must lose it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The bed sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No way to wipe his mouldy chaps?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: That we know

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To any honest well-deserving fellow,
And 'twere but to a merry cobbler, I could sit still now,
I love the game so well, but that this puckfist,
This universal rutter, fare ye well sir;
And if you have any good prayers, put 'em forward,
There may be yet a remedy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I wish it,Exit Rut.
And all my best devotions offer to it.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now is this tie dispatched?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I think it be sir:

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And my bed ready?Wine

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: There you may quickly find sir,
Such a loathed preparation.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Never grumble,
Nor fling a discontent upon my pleasure
It must and shall be done: give me some wine,
And fill it till it leap upon my lips:
Here's to the foolish maiden head you wot of,
The toy I must take pains for

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I beseech your lordship
Load not a father's love,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Pledge it Charino,
Or by my life I'll make thee pledge thy last
And be sure she be a maid, a perfect virgin,
(I will not have my expectation dulled)
Or your old pate goes off. I am hot and fiery
And my blood beats alarms through my body
And fancy high. You of my guard retire,
And let me hear no noise about the lodging
But music and sweet airs, now fetch your daughter,
And bid the coy wench put on all her beauties,
All her enticements, out-blush damask roses,
And dim the breaking East with her bright crystals.
I am all on fire, away

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And I am frozen. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Zenocia with bow and quiver, an arrow bent, Arnoldo and Rutillio after her, armed.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Come fearless on

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nay an I budge from thee
Beat me with dirty sticks.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: What masque is this?
What pretty fancy to provoke me high?
The beauteous huntress, fairer far, and sweeter;
Diana shows an Aethiop to this beauty
Protected by two virgin knights.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's a lie,
A loud one, if you knew as much as I do
The guard's dispersed

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fortune I hope invites us

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I can no longer hold, she pulls my heart from me

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Stand, and stand fixed, move not a foot, nor speak not,
For if thou dost 'Upon this point thy death sits.
Thou miserable, base, and sordid lecher,
Thou scum of noble blood, repent and speedily,
Repent thy thousand thefts, from helpless virgins,
Their innocence betrayed to thy embraces.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The base dishonour, that thou dost to strangers,
In glorying to abuse the laws of marriage,
Thy infamy thou hast flung upon thy country,
In nourishing this black and barbarous custom

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My guard.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: One word more, and thou diest.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One syllable
That tends to any thing, but I beseech you,
And as you're gentlemen tender my case,
And I'll thrust my javelin down thy throat
Thou dog-whelp, thou, pox upon thee, what
Should I call thee? Pompean,
Thou kiss my lady? thou scour her chamber pot:
Thou have a maiden head? A motley coat,
You great blind fool, farewell and be hanged to ye,
Lose no time lady.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray take your pleasure sir,
And so we'll take our leaves

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are determined,
Die, before yield

sp.speaker: Arn
sp.l: Honour, and a fair grave

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: Before a lust full bed, so for our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Du cat a whee, good count, cry, prithee cry,
Oh what a wench hast thou lost? cry you great booby.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And is she gone then, am I dishonoured thus
Cozened and baffled? my guard there no man answer?
My guard I say, sirrah you knew of this plot.
Where are my guard? I'll ha' your life you villain.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You politic old thief.
Heaven send her far enoughEnter guard.
And let me pay the ransom.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Did your honour call us?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Post every way, and presently recover,
The two strange gentlemen, and the fair lady,

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: This day was married sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We saw 'em
Making with all main speed to'th port.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away villains. Ex. guard:
Recover her, or I shall die; deal truly,
Didst not thou know,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: By all that's good I did not
If your honour mean their flight, to say I grieve for that,
Will be to lie; you may handle me as you please.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be sure, with all the cruelty, with all the rigor,
For thou hast robbed me villain of a treasure.

div.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: They're all aboard, a bark road ready for 'em,
And now are under sail and past recovery

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Rig me a ship with all the speed that may be,
I will not lose her: thou her most false father,
Shalt go along; and if I miss her, hear me,
Whole day will I study to destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I shall be joyful of it; and so you'll find me.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Manuel du sosa. and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I hear, and see, too much of him, and that
Compels me madam, though unwillingly,
To wish I had no uncle's part in him,
And much I fear, the comfort of a son
You will not long enjoy.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fault,
And therefore from his guilt my innocence
Cannot be tainted, since his father's death
(Peace to his soul) a mother's prayers and care,
Were never wanting, in his education.
His childhood I pass, as being brought up
Under my wing; and growing ripe for study,
I overcame the tenderness, and joy
I had to look upon him, and provided
The choicest masters, and of greatest name
Of Salamanca, in all liberal arts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To train his youth up.
I must witness that.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How there he prospered, to the admiration,
Of all that knew him, for a general scholar,
Being one of note, before he was a man,
Is still remembered in that academy,
From thence I sent him to the emperor's court,
Attended like his father's son and there
Maintained him, in such bravery and height,
As did become a courtier.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Twas that spoilt him, my nephew had been happy
The court's a school indeed, in which some few
Learn virtuous principles, but most forget,
Whatever they brought thither good and honest.
Trifling is there in practice, serious actions,
Are obsolete and out of use, my nephew
Had been a happy man, had he never known
What's there in grace, and fashion.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I have heard yet,
That while he lived in court, the emperor
Took notice of his carriage and good parts,
The grandees did not scorn his company,
And of the greatest ladies he was held,
A complete gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He indeed danced well,
A turn o'th toe, with a lofty trick or two,
To argue nimbleness, and a strong back,
Will go far with a madam: 'tis most true,
That he's an excellent scholar, and he knows it;
An exact courtier, and he knows that too;
He has fought thrice, and come off still with honour,
Which he forgets not

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Nor I have much reason.
To grieve his fortune that way,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are mistaken,
Prosperity does search a gentleman's temper,
More than his adverse fortune: I have known
Many, and of rare parts from their success
In private duels, raised up to such a pride,
And so transformed from what they were, that all
That loved them truly, wished they had fallen in them.
I need not write examples, in your soon,
'Tis too apparent; for ere don Duarte,
Made trial of his valour, he indeed was
Admired for civil courtesy, but now
He's swollen so high, out of his own assurance,
Of what he dares do, that he seeks occasions,
Unjust occasions, grounded on blind passion,
Ever to be in quarrels, and this makes him
Shunned of all fair societies.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Would it were
In my weak power to help it: I will use
With my entreaties th' authority of a mother,
As you may of an uncle, and enlarge it
With your command, as being a governor
To the great King in Lisbon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Here he comes.
We are unseen, observe him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Boy

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What saith the Spanish captain that I struck,
To my bold challenge?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: He refused to read it.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Why didst not leave it there?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I did my lord,
But to no purpose, for he seems more willing
To sit down with the wrongs, than to repair
His honour by the sword; he knows too well,
That from your lordship nothing can be got
But more blows, and disgraces.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: He's a wretch,
A miserable wretch, and all my fury
Is lost upon him; holds the mask, appointed
Ith' honour of Hippolita:

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis broke off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: The reason?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This was one, they heard your lordship
Was by the lady's choice to lead the dance,
And therefore they, too well assured how far
You would out shine 'em, gave it o'er and said
They would not serve for foils to set you off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: They at their best are such, and ever shall be
Where I appear.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do you note his modesty?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: But was there nothing else pretended?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes,
Young don Alonzo, the great captain's nephew,
Stood on comparisons.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: With you,
And openly professed, that all precedence,
His birth and state considered, was due to him
Nor were your lordship to contend with one
So far above you.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I look down upon him
With such contempt and scorn, as on my slave,
He's a name only, and all good in him,
He must derive, from his great grandsires ashes,
For had not their victorious acts bequeathed,
His titles to him, and wrote on his forehead,
This is a lord, he had lived unobserved
By any man of mark, and died as one
Among the common rout, compare with me?
'Tis giantlike ambition; I know him,
And know myself, that man is truly noble,
And he may justly call that worth his own,
Which his deserts have purchased, I could wish
My birth were more obscure, my friends and kinsmen
Of lesser power, or that my provident father,
Had been like to that riotous emperor
That chose his belly for his only heir;
For being of no family then, and poor
My virtues wheresoever I lived, should make
That kingdom my inheritance.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Strange self love

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For if I studied the country's laws,
I should so easily, sound all their depth,
And rise up such a wonder, that the pleaders,
That now are in most practice, and esteem
Should starve for want of clients: if I travelled,
Like wise Ulysses to see men and manners,
I would return in act, more knowing, than
Homer could fancy him; if a physician,
So oft I would restore death wounded men,
That where I lived, Galen should not be named,
And he that joined again the scattered limbs
Of torn Hippolytus should be forgotten.
I could teach Ovid courtship, how to win,
A Julia, and enjoy her, though her dower
Were all the sun gives light to: and for arms
Were the Persian host that drank up rivers, added
To the Turks present powers, I could direct,
Command, and marshal them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And yet you know not
To rule yourself, you would not to a boy else
Like Plautus' braggart boast thus.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All I speak,
In act I can make good,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Why then being master,
Of such and so good parts do you destroy them,
With self opinion or like a rich miser,
Hoard up the treasures you possess, imparting,
Nor to yourself nor others, the use of them?
They are to you, but like enchanted viands,
On which you seem to feed, yet pine with hunger;
And those so rare perfections in my son
Which would make others happy, renders me
A wretched mother.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are too insolent.
And those too many excellencies, that feed
Your pride, turn to a pleurisy, and kill
That which should nourish virtue; dare you think
All blessings are conferred on you alone.
You're grossly cozened; there's no good in you,
Which others have not: are you a scholar? so
Are many, and as knowing: are you valiant?
Waste not that courage then in braules, but spend it
In the wars, in service of your King and country.

sp.speaker: Duarte.
sp.l: Yes, so I might be general, no man lives,
That's worthy to command me

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, in Lisbon
I am: and you shall know it; every hour
I am troubled with complaints of your behaviour
From men of all conditions, and all sexes.
And my authority, which you presume
Will bear you out, in that you are my nephew,
No longer shall protect you, for I vow
Though all that's past I pardon, I will punish
The next fault with as much severity
As if you were a stranger, rest assured on't.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And by that love you should bear, or that duty
You owe a mother, once more I command you
To cast this haughtiness off; which if you do,
All that is mine, is yours, if not, expect
My prayers, and vows, for your conversion only,
But never means nor favour. Exit. Manuel and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am tutored
As I if I were a child still, the base peasants
That fear, and envy my great worth, have done this;
But I will find them out, I will aboard
Yet my disguise, I have too long been idle
Nor will I curb my spirit, I was born free,
And will pursue the course best liketh me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Divide the spoil amongst you, this fair captive
I only challenge for myself.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: You have won her
And well deserve her: twenty years I have lived
A burgess of the sea, and have been present
At many a desperate fight, but never saw
So small a bark with such incredible valour
So long defended, and against such odds,
And by two men scarce armed too.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: 'Twas a wonder.
And yet the courage they expressed being taken
And the contempt of death won more upon me
Then all they did, when they were free: methinks
I see them yet when they were brought aboard us,
Disarmed and ready to be put in fetters
How on the sudden, as if they had sworn,
Never to taste the bread of servitude,
Both snatching up their swords, and from this virgin,
Taking a farewell only with their eyes,
They leapt into the sea.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Indeed 'twas rare.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: It wrought so much on me, that but I feared,
The great ship that pursued us, our own safety
Hindering my charitable purpose to 'em,
I would have taken 'em up, and with their lives
They should have had their liberties.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: O too late
For they are lost, for ever lost

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Take comfort
'Tis not impossible, but that they live yet,
For when they left the ships they were within
A league o'th shore, and with such strength and cunning
They swimming, did delude the rising billows,
With one hand making way, and with the other,
Their bloody swords advanced, threatening the seagods
With war, unless they brought them safely off,
That I am almost confident they live
And you again may see them.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: In that hope
I brook a wretched being, till I am
Made certain of their fortunes, but they dead
Death hath so many doors to let out life,
I will not long survive them.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Hope the best,
And let the courteous usage you have found,
Not usual in men of war persuade you
To tell me your condition.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You know it,
A captive, my fate and your power have made me,
Such I am now, but what I was it skills not:
For they being dead, in whom I only live
I dare not challenge family, or country
And therefore sir inquire not, let it suffice,
I am your servant, and a thankful servant,
(If you will call that so, which is but duty)
I ever will be, and my honour safe,
Which nobly hitherto ye have preserved
No slavery can appear in such a form,
Which with a masculine constancy, I will not
Boldly look on and suffer.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: You mistake me:
That you are made my prisoner, may prove
The birth of your good fortune. I do find
A winning language in your tongue and looks;
Nor can a suit by you moved be denied,
And therefore of a prisoner you must be
The victor's advocate

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A lady.
In whom all graces that can perfect beauty
Are friendly met, I grant that you are fair:
And had I not seen her before, perhaps
I might have sought to you

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: This I hear gladly,

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: To this incomparable lady I will give you,
(Yet being mine, you are already hers)
And to serve her is more than to be free,
At least I think so: and when you live with her,
If you will please to think on him that brought you
To such a happiness, for so her bounty
Will make you think her service, you shall ever
Make me at your devotion

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: All I can do,
Rest you assured of.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: At night I'll present you,
Till when I am your guard

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Ever your servant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To what are we reserved?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Troth 'tis uncertain,
Drowning we have scaped miraculously, and
Stand fair for ought I know for hanging; money
We have none, nor e'er are like to have; 'tis
To be doubted: besides we are strangers,
Wondrous hungry strangers; and charity
Growing cold, and miracles ceasing,
Without a conjurer's help, cannot find
When we shall eat again.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: These are no wants
If put in balance, with Zenocia's loss;
In that alone, all miseries are spoken:
Oh my Rutillio, when I think on her,
And that which she may suffer, being a captive,
Than I could curse myself, almost those powers
That send me from the fury of the ocean.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have lost a wife indeed, a fair and chaste one,
Two blessings, not found often in one woman;
But she may be recovered, questionless
The ship that took us was of Portugal
And he in Lisbon, by some means or other
We may hear of her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In that hope I live.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And so do I, but hope is a poor salad
To dine and sup with, after a two days fast too,
Have you no money left?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Not a denier,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nor any thing to pawn? 'tis now in fashion,
Having a mistress, sure you should not be
Without a neat historical shirt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: For shame
Talk not so poorly.
I must talk of that
Necessity prompts us to, for beg I cannot,
Nor am I made to creep in at a window,
To filch to feed me, something must be done,
And suddenly resolve on't.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One by his habit is a Jew

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: No more:
Thou art sure that's he.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: How long is it
Since first she saw him?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Some two hours. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be gone — let me alone to work him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How he eyes you,
Now he moves, towards us, in the devil's name
What would he with us?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Innocence is bold:
Nor can I fear

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: That you are poor and strangers,
I easily perceive

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But that you'll help us,
Or any of your tribe, we dare not hope sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Because you are a Jew sir,
And courtesies come sooner from the devil
Then any of your nation.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: We are men,
And have like you, compassion when we find
Fit subjects for our bounty, and for proof
That we dare give, and freely, not to you sir,
Pray spare your pains, there's gold, stand not amazed,
'Tis current I assure you

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Take it man.
Sure thy good angel is a Jew, and comesTapers ready.
In his own shape to help thee: I could wish now,
Mine would appear so, like a Turk.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I thank you,
But yet must tell you, if this be the prologue
To any bad act, you would have me practice
I must not take it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is but the earnest
Of that which is to follow, and the bond
Which you must seal to for't, is your advancement,
Fortune with all that's in her power to give,
Offers herself up to you; entertain her,
And that which princes have kneeled for in vain
Presents itself to you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis above wonder

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But far beneath the truth, in my relation
Of what you shall possess, if you embrace it.
There is an hour in each man's life appointed
To make his happiness if then he seize it,
And this, (In which, beyond all expectation,
You are invited to your good) is yours,
If you dare follow me, so, if not, hereafter
Expect not the like offer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis no vision.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis gold I'm sure. We must like brother's share,
There's for you; by this light I'm glad I have it.
There are few gallants, (For men may be such
And yet want gold, yea and sometimes silver,)
But would receive such favours from the devil,
Though he appeared like a broker, and demanded
Sixty ith' hundred.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wherefore should I fear,
Some plot upon my life? 'tis now to me
Not worth the keeping. I will follow him,
Farewell, wish me good fortune, we shall meet
Again I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Or I'll never trust Jew more. Exit Arnoldo.
Nor Christian for his sake — plague of my stars,
How long might I have walked without a cloak,
Before I should have met with such a fortune?
We elder brothers, though we are proper men,
Ha not the luck. Have too much beard, that spoils us;
The smooth chin carries all? what's here to do now?

div.stage: Enter duart, Alonso, and a page.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'll take you as I find you:

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That were base — you see I am unarmed.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Out with your bodkin
Your pocket dagger, your steletto, out with it,
Or by this hand I'll kill you: such as you are
Have studied the undoing of poor cutlers,
And made all manly weapons out of fashion:
You carry poniards to murder men,
Yet dare not wear a sword to guard your honour.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's true indeed: upon my life this gallant
Is bribed to repeal banished swords.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'll show you
The difference now, between a Spanish rapier
And your pure pisa.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Let me fetch a sword,
Upon mine honour I'll return.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Or lend me yours I pray you, and take this,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To be disgraced as you are, no I thank you
Spite of the fashion, while I live, I amLights ready.
Instructed to go armed: what folly 'tis
For you that are a man, to put yourself
Into your enemy's mercy.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yield it quickly
Or I'll cut off your hand, and now disgrace you,
Thus kick and baffle you: as you like this
You may again prefer complaints against me
To my uncle and my mother, and then think
To make it good with a poniard.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am paid
For being of the fashion.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Get a sword,
Then if you dare, redeem your reputation:
You know I am easily found: I'll add this to it
To put you in mind.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are too insolent,
And do insult too much on the advantage,
Of that which your unequal weapon gave you,
More than your valour.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: This to me you peasant?
Thou art not worthy of my foot poor fellow,
'Tis scorn, not pity, makes me give thee life:
Kneel down and thank me for't: how, do you stare?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have a sword sir, you shall find, a good one;
This is no stabbing guard.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Wert thou thrice armed,
Thus yet I durst attempt thee:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Then have at you,
I scorn to take blows.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O I am slain.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Help! murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Shift for yourself you are dead else,
You have killed the governors nephew.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Raise the streets there.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: If once you are beset you cannot scape,
Will you betray yourself?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Undone for ever. Exit Rut. and Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Who makes this outcry,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O my lord is murdered;
This way he took, make after him,
Help help there. Exit page.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: 'Tis done Duart.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: Pride has got a fall
He was still in quarrels, scorned us peacemakers,
And all our bill-authority, now has paid for't.
You ha' met with your match sir now, bring off his body
And bear it to the governor. Some pursue
The murderer; yet if he scape, it skills not;
Were I a prince, I would reward him for't,
He has rid the city of a turbulent beast,
There's few will pity him: but for his mother
I truly grieve indeed, she's a good lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: He's not i'th house,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No madam:

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Haste and seek him,
Go all and everywhere , I'll not to bed
Till you return him, take away the lights too,
The moon lends me too much, to find my fears,
And those devotions I am to pay
Are written in my heart, not in this book,Kneel.
And I shall read them there without a taper,Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am pursued; all the ports are stopped too;
Not any hope to escape, behind, before me,
On either side I am beset, cursed fortune
My enemy on the sea, and on the land too,
Redeemed from one affliction to another:
Would I had made the greedy waves my tomb
And died obscure, and innocent, not as Nero
Smeared o'er with blood. Whither have my fears brought me?
I am got into a house, the doors all open,
This, by the largeness of the room, the hangings,
And other rich adornments, glistering through
The sable mask of night, says it belongs
To one of means and rank: no servant stirring?
Murmur nor whisper?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: By the voice,
This is a woman.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Stephano, Jaspe, Julia,
Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis the lady of the house
I'll fly to her protection.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Speak, what are you?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Of all that ever breathed, a man most wretched.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I am sure you are a man of most ill manners,
You could not with so little reverence else
Press to my private chamber. Whither would you,
Or what do you seek for?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Gracious woman hear me;
I am a stranger, and in that I answer
All your demands, a most unfortunate stranger,
That called unto it by my enemy's pride,
Have left him dead it'h streets, justice pursues me,
And for that life, I took unwillingly,
And in a fair defence, I must lose mine,
Unless you in your charity protect me.
Your house is now my sanctuary, and the altar,
I gladly would take hold of your sweet mercy.
By all that's dear unto you, by your virtues,
And by your innocence, that needs no forgiveness
Take pity on me.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Are you a Castillian:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No madam, Italy claims my birth.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I ask not
With purpose to betray you, if you were
Ten thousand times a Spaniard, the nation
We Portugals most hate, I yet would save you
If it lay in my power: lift up these hangings;
Behind my bed's head there's a hollow place,
Into which enter; so, but from this stir not
If the officers come, as you expect they will do,
I know they owe such reverence to my lodgings
That they will easily give credit to me
And search no further.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The blessed saints pay for me
The infinite debt I owe you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How he quakes?
Thus far I feel his heart beat, be of comfort,
Once more I give my promise for your safety,
All men are subject to such accidents,
Especially the valiant; and who knows not,
But that the charity I afford this stranger
My only son elsewhere may stand in need of?

div.stage: Enter officers and servants with the body of duart — page.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Now madam, if your wisdom ever could
Raise up defences against floods of sorrow
That hast to overwhelm you, make true use of
Your great discretion.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Your only son
My lord duart's slain.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: His murderer, pursued by us
Was by a boy discovered
Entering your house, and that induced us
To press into it for his apprehension.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Sure her heart is broke.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Stand off,
My sorrow is so dear and precious to me,
That you must not partake it, suffer itHold a purse ready.
Like wounds that do breed inward to dispatch me.
O my Duart, such an end as this
Thy pride long since did prophesy; thou art dead,
And to increase my misery, thy sad mother?
Must make a wilful shipwreck of her vow
Or thou fall unrevenged. My soul's divided
And piety to a son, and true performance
Of hospitable duties to my guest,
That are to others angels, are my furies.
Vengeance knocks at my heart, but my word given
Denies the entrance, is no medium left,
But that I must protect the murderer
Or suffer in that faith he made his altar?
Motherly love give place, the fault made this way,
To keep a vow, to which high heaven is witness,
Heaven may be pleased to pardon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis too late
He's gone, passed all recovery: now reproof
Were but unseasonable when I should give comfort,
And yet remember sister.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O forbear,
Search for the murderer, and remove the body,
And as you think fit, give it burial.
Wretch that I am, uncapable of all comfort,
And therefore I entreat my friends and kinsfolk,
And you my lord, for some spare to forbear
Your courteous visitations.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We obey you. Exeunt omnes with the body. Manet Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My spirits come back, and now despair resigns
Her place again to hope.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Whate'er thou art
To whom I have given means of life, to witness
With what religion I have kept my promise,
Come fearless forth, but let thy face be covered,
That I hereafter be not forced to know thee,
For motherly affection may return
My vow once paid to heaven. Thou hast taken from me,
The respiration of my heart, the light
Of my swollen eyes, in his life that sustained me,
Yet my word given to save you, I make good,
Because what you did, was not done with malice,
You are not known, there is no mark about you
That can discover you; let not fear betray you.
With all convenient speed you can, fly from me
That I may never see you; and that want
Of means may be no let unto your journey,
There are a hundred crowns: you are at the door now,
And so farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let me first fall
Before your feet, and on them pay the duty
I owe your goodness; next all blessings to you,
And heaven restore the joys I have bereft you,
With full increase hereafter, living be
The goddess styled of hospitality.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fling off these sullen clouds, you are entered now
Into a house of joy and happiness,
I have prepared a blessing for ye.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thank ye

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are peevish
And know not when ye are friended, I have used those means
My state would rather ask a curse,
The lady of this house, the noble lady,
Will take ye as her own, and use ye graciously:
Make much of what you are, mistress of that beauty,
And expose it not to such betraying sorrows:
When ye are old, and all those sweets hang withered,
Then sit and sight

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: My autumn is not far off,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Have you told your lady

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes sir, I have told her
Both of your noble service, and your present,
Which she accepts,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I should be blessed to see her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: That now you cannot do: she keeps her chamber
Not well disposed; and has denied all visits,
The maid I have in charge to receive from ye,
So please you render her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: With all my service,
But fain I would have seen,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis but your patience;
No doubt she cannot but remember nobly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: These three years I have loved this scornful lady,
And followed her with all the truth of service,
In all which time, but twice she has honoured me
With sight of her blessed beauty: when you please sir,
You may receive your charge, and tell your lady;
A gentleman whose life is only dedicated,
To her commands, kisses her beauteous hands;
And fair-one, now your help, you may remember
The honest courtesies, since you are mine
I ever did your modesty: you shall be near her,
And if sometimes you name my service to her
And tell her with what nobleness I love her,
'Twill be a gratitude I shall remember.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What in my poor power lies, so it be honest.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You must along with me (Fair)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And so I leave you two: but to a fortune
Too happy for my fate: you shall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be quick, be quick, out with the bucket there,
These scents are dull; cast richer on, and fuller;
Sent every place, where have you placed the music?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here they stand ready sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis well, be sure
The wines be lusty, high, and full of spirit,
And ambered all.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Give fair attendance.
In the best trim, and state, make ready all. Banquet set forth exit.
I shall come presently again.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: We shall sir,
What preperation's this?
Some new device
My lady has in hand,

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: O, prosper it
As long as it carries good wine in the mouth?
And good meat with it, where are all the rest

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: They are ready to attend.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sure some great person,Music
They would not make this hurry else.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: Hark the music.
It will appear now certain, here it comes.
Now to our places.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whether will he lead me?
What invitations this? to what new end,
Are these fair preparations? A rich banquet,
Music, and every place stuck with adornment,
Fit for a prince's welcome; what new game
Has fortune now prepared to show me happy?
And then again to sink me? 'tis no illusion.
Mine eyes are not deceived, all these are real;
What wealth and state?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Will you sit down and eat sir?
These carry little wonder, they are usual;
But you shall see, if you be wise to observe it,
That that will strike indeed: strike with amazement,
Then if you be a man: this fair health to you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What shall I see? I pledge ye sir, I was never
So buried in amazement —

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are so still
Drink freely.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The very wines are admirable:
Good sir, give me leave to ask this question,
For what great worthy man, are these prepared?
And why do you bring me hither?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are for you, sir;
And undervalue not the worth you carry,
You are that worthy man: think well of these.
They shall be more, and greater.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, blind fortune
Thou hast the prettiest changes when thou art pleased,
To play thy game out wantonly —

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Come be lusty
And awake your spirits. Cease music

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good sir, do not wake me.
For willingly I would die in this dream, pray whose servants
Are all these that attend her?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are yours;
They wait on you,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I never yet remember
I kept such faces, nor that I was ever able
To maintain so many.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Now you are, and shall be,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You'll say this house is mine too?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Say it? swear it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And all this wealth?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is the least you see sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, where has this been hid these thirty years?
For certainly I never found I was wealthy
Till this hour, never dreamed of house, and servants,
I had thought I had been a younger brother, a poor gent.
I may eat boldly then.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis prepared for ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The taste is perfect, and most delicate:
But why for me? give me some wine, I do drink;
I feel it sensibly, and I am here,
Here in this glorious place: I am bravely used too,
Good gentle sir, give me leave to think a little
For either I am much abused —

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Strike music
And sing that lusty song. Music song.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Bewitching harmony!
Sure I am turned into another creature.
Happy and blessed, Arnoldo was unfortunate;
Ha? bless mine eyes; what precious piece of nature
To pose the world?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I told you, you would see that,
Would darken these poor preparations;
What think ye now? nay rise not, 'tis no vision.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis more: 'tis miracle.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It speaks, and entertains me still more glorious;
She is warm, and this is flesh here: how she stirs me.
Bless me what stars are there?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: May I sit near ye?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, you are too pure an object to behold,
Too excellent to look upon, and live;
I must remove.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: She is a woman sir,
Fie, what faint heart is this

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The house of wonder.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Do not you think yourself now truly happy?
You have the abstract of all sweetness by ye,
The precious wealth youth labours to arrive at
Nor is she less in honour, then in beauty,
Ferrara's, royal Duke, is proud to call her
His best, his noblest, and most happy sister,
Fortune has made her mistress of herself,
Wealthy, and wise, without a power to sway her,
Wonder of Italy, of all heart's mistress.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: And all this is —

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Hyppolita the beauteous.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are a poor relator of my fortunes,
Too weak a chronicle to speak my blessings,
And leave out that essential part of story
I am most high and happy in, most fortunate,
The acquaintance, and the noble fellowship
Of this fair gentleman: pray ye do not wonder,
Nor hold it strange to hear a handsome lady
Speak freely to ye: with your fair leave and courtesy
I will sit by ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I know not what to answer,
Nor where I am, nor to what end consider;
Why do you use me thus?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are ye angry sir,
Because ye are entertained with all humanity?
Freely and nobly used?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No gentle lady
That were uncivil, but it much amazes me
A stranger, and a man of no desert
Should find such floods of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I love ye,
I honour ye, the first and best of all men,
And where that fair opinion leads, 'tis usual
These trifles that but serve to set off, follow,
I would not have you proud now, nor disdainful
Because I say I love ye, though I swear it,
Nor think it a stale favour I fling on ye,
Though ye be handsome, and the only man
I must confess I ever fixed mine eye on,
And bring along all promises that please us,
Yet I should hate ye then, despise ye, scorn ye,
And with as much contempt pursue your person,
As now I do with love. But you are wiser,
At least I think, more master of your fortune,
And so I drink your health.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Hold fast good honesty,
I am a lost man else.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Now you may kiss me,
'Tis the first kiss, I ever ask, I swear to ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That I dare do sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You do it well too;
You are a master sir, that makes you coy.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Would you would send your people off.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Well thought on.
Wait all without. Exit. Zab. and servants

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I hope she is pleased thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why stand ye still? here's no man to detect ye,
My people are gone off: come, come, leave conjuring
The spirit you would raise, is here already
Look boldly on me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: O most unmanly question! have you do?
Is't possible your years should want a tutor?
I'll teach ye: come, embrace me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Fie stand off;
And give me leave, more now, then ere, to wonder,
A building of so goodly a proportion,
Outwardly all exact, the frame of heaven,
Should hide within so base inhabitants?
You are as fair, as if the morning bore ye,
Imagination never made a sweeter;
Can it be possible this frame should suffer,
And built on slight affections, fright the viewer?
Be excellent in all, as you are outward,
The worthy mistress of those many blessings
Heaven has bestowed, make 'em appear still nobler,
Because they are trusted to a weaker keeper.
Would ye have me love ye?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not for your beauty;
Though I confess, it blows the first fire in us,
Time as he passes by, puts out that sparkle,
Nor for your wealth, although the world kneel to it,
And make it all addition to a woman,
Fortune that ruins all, makes that his conquest;
Be honest, and be virtuous, I'll admire ye,
At least be wise, and where ye lay these nets,
Strew over 'em a little modesty,
'Twill well become your cause, and catch more fools.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Could any one that loved this wholesome counsel
But love the giver more? you make me fonder:
You have a virtuous mind, I want that ornament;
Is it a sin I covet to enjoy ye?
If ye imagine I am too free a lover,
And act that part belongs to you I am silent;
Mine eyes shall speak my blushes, parley with ye,
I will not touch your hand, but with a tremble
Fitting a vestal nun; not long to kiss ye,
But gently as the air, and undiscerned too,
I'll steal it thus: I'll walk your shadow by ye,
So still and silent that it shall be equal,
To put me off, as that, and when I covet,
To give such toys as these —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A new temptation —

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Thus like the lazy minutes will I drop 'em,
Which passed once are forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Excellent vice!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Will ye be won? look steadfastly upon me,
Look manly, take a man's affections to you;
Young women, in the old world were not wont, sir,
To hang out gaudy bushes for their beauties,
To talk themselves into youngmen's affections;
How cold and dull you are?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How I stagger?
She is wise, as fair; but 'tis a wicked wisdom;
I'll choke before I yield.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Who waits within thereZabulon within.
Make ready the green chamber,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: It shall be madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am afraid she will enjoy me indeed,

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What music do ye love?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A modest tongue.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: We'll have enough of that: fie, fie, how lumpish?
In a young ladies arms, thus dull?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For heaven's sake
Profess a little goodness.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Of what country?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Nay then I know you mock me,
The Italians are not frighted with such bugbears,
Prithee go in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not well;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I'll make thee,
I'll kiss thee well:

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not sick of that sore.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Upon my conscience, I must ravish thee,
I shall be famous for the first example:
With this I'll tie ye first, then try your strength sir,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My strength, away base woman? I abhor thee.
I am not caught with stales, disease dwell with thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are ye so quick? and have I lost my wishes?
Ho, Zabulon; my servants.
Called ye madam?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is all that beauty scorned, so many sued for?
So many princes? by a stranger too?
Must I endure this?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Where's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Go presently, pursue the stranger, Zabulon.
He has broke from me, jewels I have given him:
Charge him with theft: he has stolen my love, my freedom,
Draw him before the governor, imprison him,
Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I'll teach him a new dance,
For playing fast and lose with such a lady.
Come fellows, come: I'll execute your anger,
And to the full.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: His scorn shall feel my vengeance. —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Shall I never see a lusty man again?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith mistress
You do so over-labour 'em when you have 'em,
And so dry-founder 'em, they cannot last.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Where's the Frenchman?
Alas, he's all to fitters,
And lies, taking the height of his fortune with a syringe.
He's chined, he's chined good man, he is a mourner.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What's become of the Dane?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Who? goldy-locks?
He's foul i'th touchhole; and recoils again,
The main spring's weakened that holds up his cock,
He lies at the sign of the sun, to be new breeched.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: The rutter too, is gone.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O that was a brave rascal,
He would labour like a thresher: but alas
What thing can ever last? he has been ill mewed,
And drawn too soon; I have seen him in the hospital.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: There was an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I there was an Englishman;
You'll scant find any now, to make that name good.
There was those English that were men indeed,
And would perform like men, but now they are vanished:
They are so taken up in their own country,
And so beaten off their speed, by their own women,
When they come here, they draw their legs like hackneys:
Drink, and their own devices has undone 'em.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I must have one that's strong, no life in Lisbon else,
Perfect and young: my custom with young ladies,
And high-fed city dames, will fall, and break else.
I want myself too, in mine age to nourish me:
They are are all sunk I maintained: now what's this business.
What goodly fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Why do you drag me?
Pox o your justice; let me lose.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Cannot a man fall into one of your drunken cellars,
And venture the breaking on's neck, your trapdoors open
But he must be used thus rascally?

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: What made you wand'ring
So late i'th night? you know that is imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: May be I walk in my sleep.

sp.speaker: 2 officer
sp.l: May be we'll walk ye.
What made ye wand'ring sir, into that vault
Where all the city store, and the munition lay?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I fell into't by chance, I broke my shins for't.
Your worships feel not that: I knocked my head
Against a hundred posts, would you had had it.
Cannot I break my neck in mine own defence?

sp.speaker: 2 officer
sp.l: This will not serve: you cannot put it off so,
Your coming thither was to play the villain,
To fire the powder, to blow that part oth' city.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes, with my nose: why were the trapdoors open?
Might not you fall, or you? had you gone that way?
I thought your city had sunk.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: You did your best sir,
We must presume to help it into'th air.
If you call that sinking: we have told you what's the law,
He that is taken there, unless a magistrate,
And have command in that place, presently
If there be nothing found apparent, near him
Worthy his torture, or his present death,
Must either pay his fine for his presumption,
(Which is six hundred ducats) or for six years
Tug at an oar i'th galleys: will ye walk sir,
For we presume you cannot pay the penalty.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Row in the galleys, after all this mischief?

sp.speaker: 2 officer
sp.l: May be you were drunk, they'll keep you sober there.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Tug at an oar? you are not arrant rascals,
To catch me in a pitfall, and betray me,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: A lusty minded man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: A wondrous able.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen, allow me but that liberty
To speak a few words with your prisoner
And I shall thank you.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Take your pleasure, lady.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What would you give that woman should redeem ye,
Redeem ye from this slavery?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Besides my service
I would give her my whole self, I would be her vassal.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: She has reason to expect as much, considering
The great sum she pays for't, yet take comfort
What ye shall do to merit this, is easy
And I will be the woman shall befriend ye,
'Tis but to entertain some handsome ladies,
And young fair gentlewomen: you guess the way:
But giving of your mind —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am excellent at it:
You cannot pick out such another living.
I understand ye: is't not thus?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Ye have it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Bring me a hundred of 'em: I'll dispatch 'em,
I will be none but yours: should another offer
Another way to redeem me, I should scorn it.
What women you shall please: I am monstrous lusty:
Not to be taken down: would you have children?
I'll get you those as fast, and thick as fly-blows.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I admire him: wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Hark ye lady,
You may require sometimes —

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And you shall have it by my faith, and handsomely:
This old cat will suck shrewdly: you have no daughters?
I fly at all: now am I in my kingdom,
Tug at an oar? no, tug in a featherbed,
With good warm candles; hang your bread and water,
I'll make you young again, believe that lady.
I will so furbish you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Come, follow officers,
This gentleman is free: I'll pay the ducats.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And when you catch me in your city-powdering-tub
Again, boil me with cabbage.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: You are both warned and armed sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Will your ladyship wear this dressing?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Leave thy prating:
I care not what I wear.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Yet 'tis my duty
To know your pleasure, and my worst affection
To see you discontented.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Weeping too?
Prithee forgive me: I am much distempered,
And speak I know not what: to make thee amends
The gown that I wore yesterday, is thine;
Let it alone a while.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now you perceive,
And taste her bounty.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Much above my merit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But have you not yet found a happy time
To move for me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I have watched all occasions,
But hitherto, without success: yet doubt not
But I'll embrace the first means.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do, and prosper;
Excellent creature, whose perfections make
Even sorrow lovely, if your frowns thus take me
What would your smiles do?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pox o this stale courtship:
If I have any power.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am commanded,
Obedience is the lover's sacrifice
Which I pay gladly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: To be forced to woo,
Being a woman, could not but torment me,
But bringing for my advocates, youth and beauty,
Set off with wealth: and then to be denied too
Does comprehend all tortures. They flattered me,
That said my looks were charms, my touches fetters,
My locks soft chains, to bind the arms of princes,
And make them in that wished for bondage, happy,
I am like others of a courser feature,
As weak to allure, but in my dotage, stronger:
I am no Circe; he, more than Ulysses,
Scorns all my offered bounties, slights my favours,
And, as I were some new Egyptian, flies me,
Leaving no pawn, but my own shame behind him.
But he shall find, that in my fell revenge,
I am a woman: one that never pardons
The rude contemner of her proffered sweetness.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis done;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What's done?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: The uncivil stranger
Is at your suit arrested.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis well handled.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: And under guard sent to the governor,
With whom my testimony, and the favour,
He bears your ladyship, have so prevailed
That he is sentenced.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To lose his head.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is that the means to quench the scorching heat
Of my enraged desires? must innocence suffer,
'Cause I am faulty? or is my love so fatal
That of necessity it must destroy
The object it most longs for? dull Hypollita,
To think that injuries could make way for love,
When courtesies were despised: that by his death
Thou shouldst give that, which only thou canst hope for
While he is living: my honours at the stake now,
And cannot be preserved, unless he perish
The enjoying of the thing I love, I ever
Have prized above my fame: why doubt I now then?
One only way is left me, to redeem all:
Make ready my caroche.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will you madam.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: And yet I am impatient of such stay:
Bind up my hair: fie, fie, while that is doing
The law may cease his life: thus, as I am then,
Not like Hypollita, but a bacchanal
My frantic love transports me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sure she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Pray you follow her: I will along with you:
I more than guess the cause: women that love
Are most uncertain, and one minute crave,
What, in another they refuse to have. Exit.

div.head: Scaena 5a.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Assure thyself Charino, I am altered
From what I was; the tempests we have met with
In our uncertain voyage, were smooth gales
Compared to those, the memory of my lusts
Raised in my conscience: and if ere again
I live to see Zenocia, I will sue,
And seek to her as a lover, and a servant,
And not command affection, like a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: In hearing this; you make me young again,
And heaven, it seems, favouring this good change in you
In setting of a period to our dangers
Gives us fair hopes, to find that here in Lisbon
Which hitherto in vain we long have sought for.
I have received assured intelligence;
Such strangers have been seen here: and though yet
I cannot learn their fortunes, nor the place
Of their abode, I have a soul presages
A fortunate event here.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: There have passed
A mutual interchange of courtesies
Between me, and the governor; therefore boldly
We may presume of him, and of his power
If we find cause to use them, otherwise
I would not be known here, and these disguises
Will keep us from discovery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The governor: with him my rival, bound.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: For certain 'tis Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let's attend
What the success will be.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is't possible
There should be hope of his recovery,
His wounds so many and so deadly?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: So they appeared at first, but the blood stopped,
His trance forsook him, and on better search
We found they were not mortal;

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Use all care
To perfect this unhoped for cure: that done
Propose your own rewards; and till you shall
Hear farther from me, for some ends I have,
Concealed it from his mother.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We'll not fail sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You still stand confident on your innocence.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: It is my best and last guard, which I will not
Leave, to rely on your uncertain mercy.

div.stage: Enter Hypolita, Zabulon, Leopold, Zenocia, 2 servants.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Who bade you follow me! Go home, and you sir,
As you respect me, go with her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Zenocia?
And in her house a servant?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My love? Contain your joy, observe the sequel. Zen. passes

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Fie madam, how undecent 'tis for you.
So far, unlike yourself to be seen thus
In th'open streets? why do you kneel? pray you rise,
I am acquainted with the wrong, and loss
You have sustained, and the delinquent now
Stands ready for his punishment.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let it fall sir,
On the offender: he is innocent
And most unworthy of these bonds he wears,
But I made up of guilt.
