sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What strange turn's this?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This was my prisoner once.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: If chastity
In a young man, and tempted to the height too
Did ere deserve reward, or admiration,
He justly may claim both. Love to his person
(Or if you please give it a fouler name)
Compelled me first to train him to my house,
All engines I raised there to shake his virtue,
Which in the assault were useless; he unmoved still
As if he had no part of humane frailty,
Against the nature of my sex, almost
I played the ravisher. You might have seen
In our contention, young Apollo fly
And lovesick Daphne follow, all arts failing,
By flight he won the victory, breaking from
My scorned embraces: the repulse (In women
Unsufferable) invited me to practise
A means to be revenged: and from this grew
His accusation, and the abuse
Of your still equal justice: my rage ever
Thanks heaven, though wanton, I found not myself
So far engaged to hell, to prosecute
To the death what I had plotted, for that love
That made me first desire him, then accuse him,
Commands me with the hazard of myself
First to entreat his pardon, then acquit him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Whate'er you are, so much I love your virtue
That I desire your friendship: do you unloose him
From those bonds, you are worthy of, your repentance
Makes part of satisfaction; yet I must
Severely reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am made
A stale on all parts: but this fellow shall
Pay dear for her favour.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My life's so full
Of various changes, that I now despair
Of any certain port; one trouble ending,
A new, and worse succeeds it: what should Zenocia
Do in this woman's house? Can chastity
And hot lust dwell together without infection?
I would not be or jealous, or secure,
Yet something must be done, to sound the depth on't:
That she lives is my bliss, but living there,
A hell of torments; there's no way to her
In whom I live, but by this door, through which
To me, 'tis death to enter, yet I must,
And will make trial.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me hear no more
Of these devices, lady: this I pardon,
And at your intercession I forgive
Your instrument the Jew too: get you home.
The hundred thousand crowns you lent the city
Towards the setting forth of the last navy
Bound for the islands, was a good then, which
I balance with your ill now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Now sir, to him,
You know my daughter needs it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let me take
A farewell with mine eye, sir, though my lip,
Be barred the ceremony, courtesy
And custom too allows of.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Gentle madam,
I neither am so cold, nor so ill bred
But that I dare receive it: you are unguarded,
And let me tell you that I am ashamed
Of my late rudeness, and would gladly therefore
If you please to accept my ready service
Wait on you to your house.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Above my hope:
Sir, if an angel were to be my convoy
He should not be more welcome. —Exit Arn. and Hyp.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now you know me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes sir, and honour you: ever remembering
Your many bounties, being ambitious only
To give you cause to say by some one service
That I am not ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Tis now offered:
I have a suit to you, and an easy one,
Which ere long you shall know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When you think fit sir,
And then as a command; I will receive it,
Till when, most welcome: you are welcome too sir,
'Tis spoken from the heart, and therefore needs not
Much protestation: at your better leisure
I will inquire the cause that brought you hither:
In the mean time serve you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You outdo me sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Duart.
sp.l: You have bestowed on me a second life
For which I live your creature, and have bettered
What nature framed unperfect, my first being
Insolent pride made monstrous; but this later
In learning me to know myself, hath taught me
Not to wrong others.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Then we live indeed.
When we can go to rest without a alarm
Given every minute to a guilt-sick conscience
To keep us waking, and rise in the morning
Secure in being innocent: but when
In the remembrance of our worser actions
We ever bear about us whips and furies,
To make the day a night of sorrow to us,
Even life's a burden.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I have found and felt it;
But will endeavour having first made peace
With those intestine enemies my rude passions
To be so with mankind: but worthy doctor,
Pray if you can resolve me; was the gentleman
That left me dead, ere brought unto his trial?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nor known, nor apprehended.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That's my grief.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Why do you wish he had been punished?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: No,
The stream of my swollen sorrow runs not that way:
For could I find him, as I vow to heaven
It shall be my first care to seek him out,
I would with thanks acknowledge that his sword,
In opening my veins, which proud blood poisoned,
Gave the first symptoms of true health.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis in you
A Christian resolution: that you live
Is by the governors, your uncle's charge
As yet concealed. And though a son's loss never
Was solemnised with more tears of true sorrow
Then have been paid by your unequalled mother
For your supposed death, she's not acquainted
With your recovery.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For some few days
Pray let her so continue: thus disguised
I may abroad unknown.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Without suspicion
Of being discovered

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am confident
No moisture sooner dies than women's tears,
And therefore though I know my mother virtuous,
Yet being one of that frail sex I purpose
Her farther trial.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: That as you think fit — I'll not betray you

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: To find out this stranger
This true physician of my mind and manners
Were such a blessing. He seemed poor, and may
Perhaps be now in want; would I could find him.
The inns I'll search first, than the public stews
He was of Italy, and that country breeds not
Precisians that way, but hot libertines;
And such the most are: 'tis but a little travail:
I am unfurnished too, pray Mr. doctor,
Can you supply me?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: With what sum you please.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I will not be long absent.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: That I wish too;
For till you have more strength, I would not have you
To be too bold.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Fear not, I will be careful. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have brought him sir, a fellow that will do it
Though hell stood in his way, ever provided
You pay him for't.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He had a strange aspect
And looks much like the figure of a hangman
In a table of the passion.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: He transcends,
All presidents believe it, a fleshed ruffian,
That hath so often taken the strappado,
That 'tis to him, but as a lofty trick
Is to a tumbler: he hath perused too,
All dungeons in Portugal, thrice seven years
Rowed in the galleys for three several murders,
Though I presume that he has done a hundred,
And scaped unpunished.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He is much indebt to you,
You set him off so well. What will you take sir
To beat a fellow for me, that thus wronged me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: To beat him say you?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Yea, beat him to lameness,
To cut his lips or nose off; any thing,
That may disfigure him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let me consider?
Five hundred pistollets for such a service
I think were no dear pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Z●b.
sp.l: Five hundred!
Why there are of your brotherhood in the city,
I'll undertake shall kill a man for twenty.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Kill him? I think so; I'll kill any man
For half the money.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And will you ask more
For a sound beating then a murder?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I sir,
And with good reason, for a dog that's dead
The Spanish proverb says, will never bite:
But should I beat or hurt him only, he may
Recover, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A good conclusion,
The obduracy of this rascal makes me tender.
I'll run some other course, there's your reward,
Without the employment.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: For that as you please sir;
When you have need to kill a man, pray use me,
But I am out at beating. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: What's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I'll tell thee Zabulon, and make thee privy
To my most near designs: this stranger, which
Hyppolita so dotes on, was my prisoner
When the last virgin, I bestowed upon her,
Was made my prize? how he escaped, hereafter
I'll let thee know; and it may be the love
He bears the servant, makes him scorn the mistress.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis not unlike; for the first time he saw her
His looks expressed so much, and for more proof
Since he came to my lady's house, though yet
He never knew her, he hath practiced with me
To help him to a conference, without
The knowledge of Hyppolita; which I promised.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And by all means perform it, for their meeting,
But work it so, that my disdainful mistress
(Whom, notwithstanding all her injuries
'Tis my hard fate to love) may see and hear them.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To what end sir?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: This Zabulon: when she sees
Who is her rival, and her lover's baseness
To leave a Princess for her bondwoman,
The sight make her scorn, what now she dotes on,
I'll double thy reward.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are like to speed then:
For I confess what you will soon believe,
We serve them best that are most apt to give.
For you I'll place you where you shall see all, and yet be unobserved.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Tat I desire too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I cannot see her yet, how it afflicts me:
The poison of this place, should mix itself
With her pure thoughts? 'twas she that was commanded
Or my eyes failed me grossly; that youth, that face
And all that noble sweetness. May she not live here,
And yet be honest still?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: It is Arnoldo,
From all his dangers free; fortune I bless thee,
My noble husband! how my joy swells in me,
But why in this place? what business hath he here?
He cannot hear of me, I am not known here.
I left him virtuous; how I shake to think now?
And how that joy I had, cools, and forsakes me?
This lady is but fair, I have been thought so
Without compare admired; she has bewitched him
And he forgotten —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: 'Tis she again, the same — the same Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: There they are together. — now you may mark

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Peace let 'em parley.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That you are well Zenocia; and once more,
Bless my despairing eyes, with your wished presence,
I thank the gods; but that I meet you here —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: They are acquainted,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I found that secret madam,
When you commanded her go home: pray hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: That you meet me here, never blush at that Arnoldo.
Your coming comes too late: I am a woman,
And one woman with another may be trusted;
Do you fear the house?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: More than a fear, I know it,
Know it not good, not honest.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What do you here then?
I'th name of virtue why do you approach it?
Will you confess the doubt and yet pursue it?
Where have your eyes been wand'ring my Arnoldo?
What constancy, what faith do you call this? Fie,
Aim at one wanton mark, and wound another?
I do confess, the lady fair, most beauteous,Leopold places himself unseen below.
And able to betray a strong man's liberty,
But you that have a love, a wife — you do well
To deal thus wisely with me: yet Arnoldo,
Since you are pleased to study a new beauty,
And think this old and ill, beaten with misery.
Study a nobler way for shame to love me,
Wrong not her honesty.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You have confirmed me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Who though she be your wife, will never hinder you,
So much I rest a servant to your wishes,
And love your loves, though they be my destructions,
No man shall know me, nor the share I have in thee,
No eye suspect, I am able to prevent you,
For since I am a slave to this great lady,
Whom I perceive you follow

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not blinded.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Fortune shall make me useful to your service,
I will speak for you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speak for me? you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I will endeavour all the ways I am able
To make her think well of you; will that please,
To make her dote upon you, dote to madness,
So far against myself I will obey you.
But when that's done, and I have showed this duty
This great obedience, few will buy it at my price,
Thus will I shake hands with you, wish you well,
But never see you more, nor receive comfort
From any thing, Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are too tender;
I neither doubt you, nor desire longer
To be a man, and live, than I am honest
And only yours; our infinite affections
Abused us both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Where are your favours now?
The courtesies you showed this stranger, madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Have I now found the cause?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Attend it further.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did she invite you do you say?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Most cunningly,
And with a preparation of that state
I was brought in and welcomed.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Seemed to love you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Most infinitely, at first sight, most dotingly.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: She is a goodly lady;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wondrous handsome:
At first view, being taken unprepared,
Your memory, not present then to assist me,
She seemed so glorious sweet, and so far stirred me,
Nay be not jealous, there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Prithee — didst thou not kiss Arnoldo?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes faith did I.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And then —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I durst not, did not —

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I forgive you,
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: May be I lay with her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He mocks me too, most basely.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did ye faith? did ye forget so far?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Come, come, no weeping;
I would have lyen first in my grave, believe that.
Why will you ask those things you would not hear?
She is too untemperate to betray my virtues
Too openly lascivious: had she dealt
But with that seeming modesty she might,
And flung a little art upon her ardour,
But 'twas forgotten, and I forgotten to like her,
And glad I was deceived. No my Zenocia,
My first love here begun, rests here unreaped yet,
And here for ever.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You have made me happy,
Even in the midst of bondage blessed.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You see now
What rubs are in your way.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: And quickly Zabulon
I'll root 'em out. — be sure you do this presently.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Do not you alter then.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I am resolute. Exit Zab.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To see you only I came hither last,
Drawn by no love of hers, nor base allurements,
For by this holy light I hate her heartily.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I am glad of that you have saved me so much vengeance
And so much fear
From this hour, fair befall you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Some means I shall make shortly to redeem you,
Till when, observe her well, and fit her temper,
Only her lust contemn.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: When shall I see you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I will live hereabouts , and bear her fair still,
Till I can find a fit hour to redeem you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Shut all the doors;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are betrayed,
The lady of the house has heard our parley,
Seen us, and seen our loves.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You courteous gallant,
You that scorn all I can bestow, that laugh at
The afflictions, and the groans I suffer for you,
That slight and jeer my love, contemn the fortune,
My favours can fling on you, have I caught you?
Have I now found the cause? ye fool my wishes?
Is mine own slave, my bane? I nourish that
That sucks up my content. I'll pray, no more,
Nor woo no more; thou shalt see foolish man,
And to thy bitter pain and anguish, look on
The vengeance I shall take, provoked and slighted;
Redeem her then, and steal her hence: ho Zabulon
Now to your work.

div.stage: Enter Zabulon and servants, some holding Arnoldo, some ready with a cord to strangle Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Lady, but hear me speak first,
As you have pity.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I have none. You taught me,
When I even hung about your neck, you scorned me.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Shall we pluck yet?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No, hold a little Zabulon,
I'll pluck his heartstrings first: now am I worthy
A little of your love?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'll be your servant,
Command me through what danger you shall aim at,
Let it be death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Be sure sir, I shall fit you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But spare this virgin;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I would spare that villain first,
Had cut my father's throat.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Bounteous lady,
If in your sex there be that noble softness,
That tenderness of heart, women are crowned for —

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Kneel not Arnoldo, do her not that honour,
She is not worthy such submission,
I scorn a life depends upon her pity.
Proud woman do thy worst, and arm thy anger,
With thoughts as black as hell, as hot and bloody,
I bring a patience here, shall make 'em blush,
An innocence, shall outlook thee, and death too.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Make me your slave, I give my freedom to ye,
For ever to be fettered to your service;
'Twas I offended, be not so unjust then,
To strike the innocent, this gentle maid,
Never intended fear and doubt against you:
She is your servant, pay not her observance
With cruel looks, her duteous faith with death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Am I fair now? now am I worth your liking?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Not fair, not to be liked, thou glorious devil,
Thou varnished piece of lust, thou painted fury.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speak gently sweet, speak gently;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'll speak nobly.
'Tis not the saving of a life I aim at,
Mark me lascivious woman, mark me truly,
And then consider, how I weigh thy angers.
Life is no longer mine, nor dear unto me,
Then useful to his honour, I preserve it
If thou hadst studied all the courtesies
Humanity and noble blood, are linked too,
Thou couldst not have propounded such a benefit,
Nor heaped upon me such unlooked for honour
As dying for his sake, to be his martyr,
'Tis such a grace.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You shall not want that favour,
Let your bones work miracles.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Dear lady
By those fair eyes —

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: There is but this way left ye
To save her life. —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speak it, and I embrace it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Come to my private chamber presently
And there, what love and I command —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'll do it,
Be comforted Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Do not do this,
To save me, do not lose yourself I charge you,
I charge you by your love, that love you bear me;
That love, that constant love you have twined to me,
By all your promises, take heed you keep 'em,
Now is your constant trial. If thou dost this,
Or movest one foot, to guide thee to her lust,
My curses and eternal hate pursue thee.
Redeem me at the base price of disloyalty?
Must my undoubted honesty be thy bawd too?
Go and intwine thyself about that body?
Tell her, for my life thou hast lost thine honour,
Pulled all thy vows from heaven, basely, most basely
To add an hour to me that hate thee for it,
Stooped to the servile flames of that foul woman
Know thee again, nor name thee for a husband.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What shall I do to save her?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How now, what haste there?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The governor, attended with some gentlemen,
Are newly entered, to speak with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pox o their business, reprieve her for this hour,
I shall have other time.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Now fortune help us.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: I'll meet 'em presently: retire a while all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You rise today upon your right side lady;
You know the danger too, and may prevent it,
And if you suffer her to perish thus,
As she must do, and suddenly believe it,
Unless you stand her friend; you know the way on't,
I guess you poorly love her, less your fortune.
Let her know nothing, and perform this matter,
There are hours ordained for several businesses,
You understand.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I understand you bawd sir,
And such a counsellor I never cared for.

div.stage: Enter the governor, Clodio, Leopold, Charino and attendants at one door, Hyppolita at the other.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Your lordship does me honour.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Fair Hyppolita,
I am come to ease you of a charge.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I keep none,
I count a burden sir: and yet I lie too.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Which is the maid; is she here?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Yes sir,
This is she, this is Zenocia,
The very same I sued to your lordship for.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Clodio again? more misery? more ruin?
Under what angry star is my life governed.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Come hither maid, you are once more a free woman
Here I discharge your bonds.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Another smile,
Another trick of fortune to betray us!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why does your lordship use me so unnobly?
Against my will, to take away my bondwoman?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: She was no lawful prize, therefore no bondwoman:
She's of that country we hold friendship with,
And ever did, and therefore to be used
With entertainment, fair and courteous.
The breach of league in us gives foul example,
Therefore you must be pleased to think this honest;
Did you know what she was?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Not till this instant;
For had I known her, she had been no prisoner.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: There, take the maid, she is at her own dispose now,
And if there be ought else to do your honour
Any poor service in —

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am vowed your servant;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your father's here too, that's our only comfort,
And in a country now, we stand free people,
Where Clodio has no power, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I fear some trick yet.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not so dejected.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You must not be displeased; so farewell lady.
Come gentlemen; captain, you must with me too,
I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I attend your lordship:
Now my way's free, and my hopes. Lords again.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Hyp. and zab.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: D'ye jeer me now ye are going?
I may live yet — to make you howl both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You might have done; you had power then,
But now the chains are off, the command lost,
And such a story they will make of this
To laugh out lazy time.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No means yet left me?
For now I burst with anger: none to satisfy me?
No comfort? no revenge?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You speak too late;
You might have had all these, your useful servants
Had you been wise, and sudden; what power, or will
Over her beauty, have you now? by violence
To constrain his love; she is as free as you are,
And no law can impeach her liberty,
And whilst she is so, Arnoldo will despise you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Either my love or anger must be satisfied,
Or I must die.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have a way would do it,
Wooed do it yet, protect me from the law.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: From any thing; thou knowest what power I have
What money, and what friends.

sp.speaker: Zab
sp.l: 'Tis a devilish one:
But such must now be used: walk in, I'll tell you;
And if you like it, if the devil can do any thing.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Devil, or what thou wilt, so I be satisfied. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: This is the rarest, and the lustiest fellow,
And so bestirs himself —

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath mistress
You'll melt him else.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: He does perform such wonders —
The women are mad on him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath I say;
The man is but a man, he must have breath.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How many had he yesterday?
And they paid bravely too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: About fourteen.
But still I cry give breath, spare him and have him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Five dames today; this was a small stage
He may endure five more.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Breath, breath I cry still;
Body o me give breath, the man's a lost man else.
Feed him and give him breath. Enter 2. gentlewomen

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Welcome gentlewomen,
You're very welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: We hear you have a lusty and well-complexioned fellow
That does rare tricks, my sister and myself here,
Would trifle out an hour or two so, please you.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Jaques, conduct 'em in.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: There's for your courtesy. Exeunt jaqu. and gent.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Good pay still, good round pay, this happy fellow
Will set me up again; he brings in gold
Faster than I have leisure to receive it.
O that his body were not flesh and fading;
But I'll so pap him up — nothing too dear for him;
What a sweet scent he has? — now what news Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He cannot last, I pity the poor man
I suffer for him; two coaches of young city dames,
And they drive as the devil were in the wheels,
Are ready now to enter: and behind these
An old dead-palsied lady in a litter,
And she makes all the haste she can: the man's lost,
You may gather up his dry bones to make ninepins,
But for his flesh.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: These are but easy labours,
Yet, for I know he must have rest.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: He must: — you'll beat him off his legs else presently.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Go in, and bid him please himself, I am pleased too:
Tomorrow's a new day; but if he can
I would have him take pity o the old lady.
Alas 'tis charity.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'll tell him all this
And if he be not too foolhardy.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How now?
What news with you?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You must presently
Show all the art you have, and for my lady.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: She may command.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You must not dream nor trifle.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: A spell you must prepare, a powerful one,
Peruse but these directions, you shall find all;
There is the picture too, be quick, and faithful,
And do it with that strength — when 'tis performed
Pitch your reward at what you please, you have it.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I'll do my best, and suddenly: but hark ye,
Will you never lie at home again?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Excuse me,
I have too much business yet.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I am right glad on't.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Think on your business, so farewell.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Within this hour I'll visit you again
And give you greater lights.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I shall observe ye;
This brings a brave reward, bravely I'll do it
And all the hidden art I have, express in't. Ex. at both doors.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now do I look as if I were crow-trodden,
Fie how my hams shrink under me; o me,
I am broken-winded too; is this a life?
Is this the recreation I have aimed at,
I had a body once, a handsome body,
And wholesome too. Now I appear like a rascal
That had been hung a year or two in gibbets.
Fie how I faint; women? keep me from women;
Place me before a cannon, 'tis a pleasure;
Stretch me upon a rac it, a recreation;
But women? women? O the devil! women?
Curtius' gulf was never half so dangerous.
Is there no way to find the trap-door again,
And fall into the cellar, and be taken?
No lucky fortune to direct me that way?
No galleys to be got, nor yet no gallows?
For I fear nothing now, no earthly thing
But these unsatisfied men-leeches, women.
How devilishly my bones ache: o the old lady!
I have a kind of waiting-woman, lies cross my back too,
Oh how she stings! no treason to deliver me?
Now what are you? do you mock me?
No sir, no,
We were your predecessors in this place,
And come to see you bear up.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good gentlemen;
You seem to have a snuffing in your head sir,
A perilous snuffing, but this same dampish air —
A dampish air indeed.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Blow your face tenderly,
Your nose will never endure it: mercy o me,
What are men changed to here? is my nose fast yet?
Methinks it shakes it'h hilts: pray tell me gentlemen,
How long is't since you flourished here?
Not long since.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Move yourself easily, I see you are tender,
Nor long endured.
The labour was so much sir
And so few to perform it. —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Must I come to this?
And draw my legs after me like a lame dog?
I cannot run away, I am too feeble:
Will you sue for this place again gentlemen?

sp.p: No truly sir, the place has been too warm for our complexions.

sp.l: We have enough on't, rest you merry sir,
We came but to congratulate your fortune,
You have abundance.
Bear your fortune soberly,
And so we leave you to the next fair lady. Exit the 3.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Stay but a little, and I'll meet you gentlemen,
At the next hospital: there's no living thus,
Nor am I able to endure it longer,
With all the helps and heats that can be given me,
I am at my trot already; they are fair and young
Most of the women that repair unto me,
But they stick on like burrs, shake me like feathers.
More women yet?
Would I were honestly married,
To any thing that had but half a face,
And not a groat to keep her, nor a smock,
That I might be civilly merry when I pleased,
Rather than labouring in these fulling mills.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: By this the spell begins to work: you are lusty,
I see you bear up bravely yet.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do you hear lady,
Do not make a game-bear of me, to play me hourly,
And fling on all your whelps; it will not hold;
Play me with some discretion; today one course,
And two days hence another.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you be so angry
Pay back the money I redeemed you at
And take your course; I can have men enough:
You have lost me an hundred crowns since you came hither,
In broths and strengthening caudles; till you do pay me
If you will eat and live, you shall endeavour,
I'll chain you to't else.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Make me a dog-ken 〈…〉
I'll keep your house and bark, 〈◊〉 feed on bare bones,
And be whipped out a door's,
Do you mark me lady? whipped,
I'll eat old shoes. Enter duart.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: In this house, I am told
There is a stranger, of a goodly person,
And such a one there was; if I could see him,
I yet remember him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Your business sir,
If it be for a woman, ye are cozened,
I keep none here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Certain this is the gentleman,
The very same.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Death, if I had but money,
Or any friend to bring me from this bondage,
I would thrash, set up a cobbler's shop, keep hogs,
And feed with 'em, sell tinder boxes,
And knights of gingerbread, thatch for three
Half pence a day, and think it lordly,
From this base stallion trade: why does he cy me,
Eye me so narrowly?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: It seems you are troubled sir,
I heard you speak of want;

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis better hearing
Far, then relieving sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I do not think so, you know me not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Not yet that I remember.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You shall, and for your friend: I am beholding to ye
Greatly beholding sir, if you remember,
You fought with such a man, they called Duart,
A proud distempered man: he was my enemy,
My mortal foe, you slew him fairly, nobly.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Speak softly sir, you do not mean to betray me
I wished the gallows, now they're coming fairly.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Be confident, for as I live, I love you,
And now you shall perceive it: for that service
Me, and my purse command: there, take it to ye,
'Tis gold, and no small sum, a thousand ducats,
Supply your want.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But do you do this faithfully?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: If I mean ill, spit in my face and kick me,
In what else I may serve you, sir —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thank you,
This is as strange to me as knight's adventure.
I have a project, 'tis an honest one,
And now I'll tempt my fortune.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are so good and honest I must trust ye,
'Tis but to carry a letter to a lady
That saved my life once.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will be most thankful,
I will do't with all care.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Where are you, white-broth?
Now lusty blood,
Come in, and tell your money:
'Tis ready here, no threats, nor no orations,
Nor prayers now.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You do not mean to leave me —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'll live in hell sooner than here, and cooler.
Come quickly come, dispatch, this airs unwholesome:
Quickly good lady, quickly to't.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Well, since it must be,
The next, I'll fetter faster sure, and closer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And pick his bones, as you're done mine, pox take ye.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: At my lodging for a while, you shall be quartered,
And there take physic for your health.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I thank ye
I have found my angel now too, if I can keep him.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You like the letter.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yes, but I must tell you,
You tempt a desperate hazard, to solicit
The mother, (And the grieved one too, 'tis rumoured)
Of him you slew so lately.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have told you
Some proofs of her affection, and I know not
A nearer way to make her satisfaction
For a lost son, then speedily to help her
To a good husband; one that will beget
Both sons and daughters, if she be not barren.
I have had a breathing now, and have recovered
What I lost in my late service, 'twas a hot one:
It fired and fired me; but all thanks to you sir,
You have both freed and cooled me.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What is done sir
I thought well done, and was in that rewarded,
And therefore spare your thanks.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'll no more whoring:
This fencing twixt a pair of sheets, more wears one
Then all the exercise in the world besides.
To be drunk with good canary, a mere julip
Or like gourd-water to 't; twenty surfeits
Come short of one nights work there. If I get this lady
As ten to one I shall; I was never denied yet,
I will live wondrous honestly; walk before her
Gravely, and demurely
And then instruct my family; you are sad,
What do you muse on sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Truth I was thinking
What course to take for the delivery of your letter,
And now I have it: but faith did this lady
(For do not gull yourself) for certain know,
You killed her son?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Give me a book, I'll swear't;
Denied me to the officers, that pursued me,
Brought me herself to'th door, then gave me gold
To bear my charges, and shall I make doubt then
But that she loved me? I am confident
Time having ta'en her grief off, that I shall be
Most welcome to her: for then to have wooed her
Had been unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Well sir, there's more money,
To make you handsome; I'll about your business:
You know where you must stay.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There you shall find me:
Would I could meet my brother now, to know,
Whether the Jew, his genius, or my christian,
Has proved the better friend. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O who would trust
Deceiving woman! or believe that one
The best, and most canonised ever was
More than a seeming goodness! I could rail now
Against the sex, and curse it; but the theme
And way's too common: yet that Guiomar
My mother; (Nor let that forbid her to be
The wonder of our nation) she that was
Marked out the great example, for all matrons
Both wife and widow; she that in my breeding
Expressed the utmost of a mother's care,
And tenderness to a son; she that yet feigns
Such sorrow for me; good God, that this mother,
After all this, should give up to a stranger,
The wreak she owed her son; I fear her honour.
That he was saved, much joys me, and grieve only
That she was his preserver. I'll try further,
And by this engine, find whether the tears,
Of which, she is so prodigal, are for me,
Or used to cloak her base hypocrisy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are you assured the charm prevails?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Do I live?
Or you speak to me? Now, this very instant
Health takes its last leave of her; maugre paleness
Like winter, nips the roses and the lilies,
The spring that youth, and love adorned her face with.
To force affection, is beyond our art,
For I have proved all means that hell has taught me,
Or the malice of a woman, which exceeds it,
To change Arnoldoe's love, but to no purpose:
But for your bondwoman.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let her pine and die;
She removed; which like a brighter sun,
Obscures my beams, I may shine out again,
And as I have been, be admired and sought to:
How long has she to live?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Lady, before
The sun twice rise and set, be confident,
She is but dead; I know my charm hath found her
Nor can the governors guard; her lovers tears;
Her father's sorrow, or his power that freed her,
Defend her from it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: All things have succeeded,
As you could wish; I saw her brought sick home;
The image of pale death, stamped on her forehead.
Let me adore this second Hecate,
This great commandress, of the fatal sisters,
That as she pleases, can cut short, or lengthen
The thread of life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Where was she, when the enchantment
First ceased upon her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Taking the fresh air,
In the company of the governor, and count Clodio
Arnoldo too, was present with her father,
When, in a moment (So the servants told me)
As she was giving thanks to the governor,
And Clodio, for her unexpected freedom,
As if she had been blasted, she sunk down,
To their amazement.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis thy masterpiece
Which I will so reward, that thou shalt fix here,
And with the hazard of thy life, no more
Make trial of thy powerful art; which known
Our laws call death: off with this magical robe,
And be thyself.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Stand close, you shall hear more.

sp.speaker: Go: Man.
sp.l: You must have patience; all rage is vain now,
And piety forbids, that we should question
What is decreed above, or ask a reason
Why heaven determines this or that way of us.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Heaven has no hand in't; 'tis a work of hell.
Her life hath been so innocent, all her actions
So free from the suspicion of crime,
As rather she deserves a saint's place here,
Then to endure, what now her sweetness suffers.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Not for her fault, but mine sir; Zenocia suffers,
The sin I made, when I sought to raze down
Arnoldos love, built, on a rock of truth,
Now to the height is punished. I profess,
Had he no birth, nor parts, the present sorrows
He now expresses for her, does deserve her
Above all Kings, though such had been his rivals.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: All ancient storeys, of the love of husbands
To virtuous wives, be now no more remembered.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The tales of turtles, ever be forgotten,
Or, for his sake believed.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I have heard, there has been
Between some married pairs, such sympathy,
That th' husband, has felt really, the throws
His wife then teeming suffers, this true grief,
Confirms, 'tis not impossible.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: We shall find
Fit time for this hereafter; let's 'Use now
All possible means to help her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Care, nor cost,
Nor what physicians can do, shall be wanting;
Make use of any means, or men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are noble. Exeunt. Man. Clod. Charino.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ten colleges of doctors shall not save her.
Her fate is in your hand.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Can I restore her?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you command my art.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll die myself first.
And yet I'll go visit her, and see
This miracle of sorrow in Arnoldo:
And 'twere for me, I should change places with her,
And die most happy, such a lover's tears,
Were a rich monument, but too good for her;
Whose misery I glory in: come Sulpitia,
You shall a long with me, good Zabulon
Be not far off.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I will attend you madam.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I have served you, from my youth, and ever
You have found me faithful: that you lives a treasure
I'll lock up here; nor shall it be let forth,
But when you give me warrant.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I rely,
Upon thy faith; nay, no more protestations,
Too many of them, will call that in question,
Which now I doubt not, she is there.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Alone too
But take it on my life your entertainment,
Appearing as you are, will be but course
For the displeasure, I shall undergo;
I am prepared.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Leave me, I'll stand the hazard. Exit servant.
The silence that's observed, her close retirements
No visitance admitted, not the day;
These sable colours, all signs of true sorrow,
Or hers is deeply counterfeit. I'll look nearer,
Manners give leave — she fits upon the ground;
By heaven she weeps; my picture in her hand too;
She kisses it and weeps again.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: There is no starting back now madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Ha, another murderer, I'll not protect thee,
Though I have no more sons.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Your pardon lady,
There's no such foul fact taints me

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: What makes thou here then?
Where are my servants, do none but my sorrows
Attend upon me? speak, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: A will, to give you comfort.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Thou art but a man.
And 'tis beyond a humane reach to do it
If thou could raise the dead out of their graves.
Bid time run back, make me now what I was,
A happy mother: gladly I would hear thee,
But that's impossible.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Please you but to read this;
You shall know better there, why I am sent
Then if I should deliver it

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: From whom comes it?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will instruct you; I suspect this stranger,
Yet she spoke something, that holds such alliance,
With his reports I know not what to think on't;
What a frown was there? she looks me through, and through,
Now reads again, now pauses, and now smiles;
And yet there's more of anger in't then mirth,
These are strange changes; o I understand it
She's full of serious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are just you heavens,
And never do forget to hear their prayers,
That truly pay their vows, the defered vengeance,
For you, and my words sake so long deferred,
Under which as a mountain, my heart groans yet
When 'twas despaired of, now is offered to me;
And if I lose it, I am both ways guilty,
The woman's mask, dissimulation help me;
Come hither friend, I am sure you know the gentleman,
That sent these charms.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: Charms lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: These charms.
I well may call them so, they've won upon me,
More than ere letter did; thou art his friend,
(The confidence he has in thee, confirms it)
And therefore I'll be open breasted to thee,
To hear of him, though yet, I never saw him,
Was most desired of all men; let me blush,
And then I'll say I love him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All men see,
In this a woman's virtue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I expected
For the courtesy I did, long since to have seen him,
And though I then forbade it, you men know,
Between our hearts and tongues, there's a large distance;
But I'll excuse him, may be hitherto,
He has forborn it, in respect my son
Fell by his hand.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: And reason lady.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: No, he did me a pleasure in't, a riotous fellow,
And with that insolent, not worth the owning ▪
I have indeed kept a long solemn sorrow,
For my friends sake partly; but especially
For his long absence.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O the devil!

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Therefore,
Bid him be speedy; a priest shall be ready
To tie the holy knot; this kiss I send him,
Deliver that and bring him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am dumb:
A good cause I have now, and a good sword,
And something I shall do, I wait upon you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mannuel. Charino. Arnoldo. Zenocia, born in a chair. 2. Doctors. Clodio.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Give her more air she dies else.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O thou dread power,
That madest this all, and of thy workmanship,
This virgin wife, the master piece, look down on her;
Let her minds virtues, clothed in this fair garment,
That worthily deserves, a better name
Than flesh and blood, now sue, and prevail for her.
Or if those are denied, let innocence,
To which, all passages in heaven stand open,
Appear in her white robe, before thy throne;
And mediate for her: or if this age of sin,
Be worthy of a miracle, the sun
In his diurnal progress never saw,
So sweet a subject to employ it on.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wonders are ceased sir, we must work by means,

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: 'Tis true and such reverend physicians are;
To you — thus low I fall then; so may you ever
Be styled the hands of heaven, natures restorers;
Get wealth and honours; and by your success,
In all your undertakings, propagate
Your great opinion in the world, as now
You use your saving art; for know good gentlemen.
Besides the fame, and all that I possess,
For a reward, posterity shall stand
Indebted to you, for (As heaven forbid it)
Should my Zenocia die, robbing this age,
Of all that's good or graceful, times succeeding,
The story of her pure life not yet perfect,
Will suffer in the want of her example.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Were all the world to perish with her, we
Can do no more; then what art and experience
Gives us assurance of, we have used all means
To find the cause of her disease, yet cannot;
How should we then, promise the cure?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Away,
I did bely you, when I charged you with
The power of doing; ye are mere names only,
And even your best perfection, accidental;
Whatever malady thou art, or spirit,
As some hold, all diseases that afflict us,
As love, already makes me sensible
Of half her sufferings, ease her of her part,
And let me stand the butt, of thy fell malice,
And I will swear thou'rt merciful.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Your hand lady;
What a strange heat is hear? bring some warm water.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: She shall use nothing that is yours; my sorrow,
Provides her of a better bath, my tears,
Shall do that office.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: O my best Arnoldo!
The truest of all lovers! I would live
Were heaven so pleased, but to reward your sorrow,
With my true service; but since that's denied me,
May you live long and happy: do not suffer,
(By your affection to me I conjure you)
My sickness to infect you; though much love
Makes you too subject to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In this only
Zenocia wrongs her servant; can the body
Subsist, the soul departed? 'tis as easy
As I to live without you; I am your husband,
And long have been so, though our adverse fortune,
Banding us, from one hazard to another,
Would never grant me so much happiness,
As to pay a husband's debt; despite of fortune,
In death I'll follow you, and guard mine own;
And there enjoy what here my fate forbids me.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: So true a sorrow, and so feelingly
Expressed, I never read of.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I am struck
With wonder to behold it, as with pity

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If you that are a stranger, suffer for them,
Being tied no further than humanity
Leads you to soft compassion; think great sir,
What of necessity I must endure,
That am a father?

div.stage: Hypolita. Zabulon and Sulpitia at the door.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Wait me there, I hold it
Unfit to have you seen; as I find cause,
You shall proceed,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are welcome lady.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Sir, I come to do a charitable office,
How does the patient?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You may inquire
Of more than one; for two are sick, and deadly,
He languishes in her, her healths, despaired of,
And in hers, his.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange spectacle,
With what a patience, they sit unmoved?
Are they not dead already?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By her pulse,
She cannot last a day.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O by that summons,
I know my time too!

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Look to the man.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Apply
Your art, to save the lady, preserve her,
A town is your reward.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I'll triple it,
In ready gold, if you restore Arnoldo;
For in his death I die too.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Without her,
I am no more.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Are you there madam? now
You may feast on my miseries; my coldness
In answering your affections; or hardness,
Give it what name you please, you are revenged of;
For now you may perceive, our thread of life
Was spun together, and the poor Arnoldo,
Made only to enjoy the best Zenocia,
And not to serve the use of any other;
And in that she may equal, my lord Clodio,
Had long since else enjoyed her, nor could I
Have been so blind, as not to see your great
And many excellencies far, far beyond
Or my deservings, or my hopes; we are now
Going our latest journey, and together,
Our only comfort we desire, pray give it
Your charity to our ashes, such we must be,
And not to curse our memories.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I am much moved.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am wholly overcome, all love to women,
Farewell for ever, ere you die, your pardon;
And yours sir; had she many years to live,
Perhaps I might look on her, as a brother,
But as a lover never; and since all
Your sad misfortunes, had original
From the barbarous custom practised in my country,
Heaven witness, for your sake I here release it;
So to your memory, chaste wives and virgins
Shall ever pay their vows. I give her to you;
And wish, she were so now, as when my lust
Forced you; to quite the country.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is in vain,
To strive with destiny, here my dotage ends,
Look up Zenocia, health in me speaks to you;
She gives him to you, that by divers ways,
So long has kept him from you: and repent not,
That you were once my servant, for which health
In recompense of what I made you suffer,
The hundred thousand crowns, the city owes me,
Shall be your dower.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis a magnificent gift,
Had it been timely given.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is believe it; Sulpitia?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Madam

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Quick, undo the charm;
Ask not a reason why; let it suffice,
It is my will.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which I obey and gladly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is to be married sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: So she says sir,
And does desire your presence. They are born off in chairs

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And tell her I'll come.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pray carry them to their rest; for though already,
They do appear as dead, let my life pay for't,
If they recover not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What you have warranted,
Assure yourself, will be expected from you;
Look to them carefully; and till the trial,

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Which shall not be above four hours.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me
Entreat your companies: there is something
Of weight, invites me hence.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We'll wait upon you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You understand what my directions are,
And what they guide you to; the faithful promise,
You have made me all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do and will perform it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: The governor will not fail to be here presently
Retire a while, till you shall find occasion,
And bring me word, when they arrive.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We shall madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Only stay you to entertain;

sp.speaker: 1. servant
sp.l: I am ready

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I wonder at the bold, and practised malice,
Men ever have a foot, against our honours,
That nothing we can do, never so virtuous,
No shape put on so pious, no not think
What a good is, be that good never so noble,
Never so laden with admired example,
But still we end in lust; our aims our actions,
Nay, even our charities, with lust are branded;
Why should this stranger else, this wretched stranger,
Whose life I saved at what dear price, stick here yet?
Why should he hope, he was not here an hour,
And certainly in that time, I may swear it
I gave him no loose look, I had no reason;
Unless my tears were flames, my curses courtships;
The killing of my son, a kindness to me,
Why should he send to me, or with what safety
(Examining the ruin he had wrought me)
Though at that time, my pious pity found him,
And my word fixed; I am troubled, strongly troubled.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Then bid 'em welcome — I must retire. Exit.
You are welcome home gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thank you friend, I would speak with your lady.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll let her understand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: It shall befit you,
How do I look sir, in this handsome trim? Exit. Servant.
Methinks I am wondrous brave.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You are very decent.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: These by themselves, without more helps of nature,
Would set a woman hard; I know 'em all,
And where their first aims light; I'll lay my head on't,
I'll take her eye, as soon as she looks on me,
And if I come to speak once, woe be to her,
I have her in a noose, she cannot scape me;
I have their several lasts.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You are thoroughly studied,
But tell me sir, being unacquainted with her,
As you confess you are —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's not an hour's work,
I'll make a nun forget her beads in two hours.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: She being set in years next, none of those lustres
Appearing in her eye,, that warm the fancy;
Nor nothing in her face, but handsome ruins.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I love old stories; those live believed, authentic,
When 20. of your modern faces, are called in,
For new opinion paintings, and corruptions,
Give me an old confirmed face; besides she saved me,
She saved my life, have I not cause to love her?
She's rich and of a constant state, a fair one
Have I not cause to woo her? I have tried sufficient,
All your young fillies, I think this back has tried 'em,
And smarted for it too: they run away with me,
Take bit between the teeth, and play the devils;
'A staied pace now becomes my years; a sure one,
Where I may sit and crack no girths.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: How miserable,
If my mother should confirm, what I suspect now,
Beyond all humane cure were my condition?
Then I shall wish, this body had been so too,
Here comes the lady sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Excellent lady,
To show I am a creature, bound to your service,
And only yours —

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Keep at that distance sir;
For if you stir —

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am obedient,
She has found already, I am for her turn;
With what a greedy hawks eye she beholds me?
Mark how she musters all my parts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: A goodly gentleman,
Of a more manly set, I never looked on.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Mark, mark her eye still; mark but the carriage of 'em

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How happy am I now; since my son fell,
He fell not, by a base unnoble hand?
As that still troubled me; how far more happy
Shall my revenge be, since the sacrifice,
I offer to his grave, shall be both worthy,
A sons untimely loss, and a mother's sorrow?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Sir, I am made believe it; she is mine own,
I told you what a spell I carried with me,
All this time does she spend, in contemplation,
Of that unmatched delight: I shall be thankful to ye;
And if you please to know my house, to use it;
To take it for your own.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who waits without there?

div.stage: Enter. Guard. and servants. they seize upon Rut. and bind him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now? what means this, lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Bind him fast.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Are these the bride-laces you prepare for me?
The colours that you give?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Fie gentle lady,
This is not noble dealing.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be you satisfied,
It seems you are a stranger to this meaning,
You shall not be so long

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do you call this wooing — is there no end of women's persecutions?
Must I needs fool into mine own destruction?
Have I not had fair warnings, and enough too?
Still pick the devil's teeth? you are not mad lady;
Do I come fairly, and like a gentleman,
To offer you that honour?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are deceived sir
You come besotted, to your own destruction:
I sent not for you; what honour can ye add to me,
That broke that staff of honour, my age leaned on?
That robbed me of that right, made me a mother?
Hear me thou wretched man, hear me with terror,
And let thine own bold folly shake thy soul,
Hear me pronounce thy death, that now hangs o'er thee,
Thou desperate fool; who bade thee seek this ruin?
What mad unmanly fate, made thee discover
Thy cursed face to me again? wast not enough
To have the fair protection of my house,
When misery and justice, close pursued thee?
When thine own bloody sword, cried out against thee,
Hatched in the life of him? yet I forgave thee;
My hospitable word, even when I saw
The goodliest branch of all my blood, lopped from me,
Did I not seal still to thee?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And when thou wentest to imp thy misery,
Did I not give thee means? but hark ungrateful,
Was it not thus? to hide thy face and fly me?
To keep thy name for ever from my memory?
Thy cursed blood and kindred; did I not swear then
If ever, (In this wretched life thou hast left me,
Short and unfortunate,) I saw thee again,
Or came but to the knowledge, where thou wanderdst,
To call my vow back, and pursue with vengeance
With all the miseries a mother suffers?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I was born to be hanged, there's no avoiding it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And dar'st thou with this impudence appear here?
Walk like the winding sheet my son was put in,
Stand with those wounds?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am happy now again;
Happy the hour I fell, to find a mother,
So pious good, and excellent in sorrows.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The governors come in.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O let him enter.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have fooled myself a fair thread of all my fortunes,
This strikes me most; not that I fear to perish,
But that this unmannerly boldness, has brought me to it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Are these fit preparations for a wedding lady?
I came prepared a guest.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O give me justice;
As ever you will leave a virtuous name,
Do justice, justice, sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You need not ask it,
I am bound to it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Justice upon this man
That killed my son.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Do you confess the act?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Rutillio?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: How fell he thus?
Here will be sorrow for the good Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Take heed sir what you say.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have weighed it well,
I am the man, nor is it life I start at;
Only I am unhappy I am poor,
Door in expense of lives, there I am wretched,
That I have not two lives lent me for his sacrifice;
One for her son, another for her sorrows.
Excellent lady, now rejoice again,
For though I cannot think, you're pleased in blood,
Nor with that greedy thirst pursue your vengeance;
The tenderness, even in those tears denies that;
Yet let the world believe, you loved Duarte;
The unmatched courtesies you have done my miseries,
Without this forfeit to the law, would charge me
To tender you this life, and proud 'twould please you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Shall I have justice?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'll ask it for ye,
I'll follow it myself, against myself.
Sir, 'tis most fit I die; dispatch it quickly,
The monstrous burden of that grief she labours with
Will kill her else, than blood on blood lies on me;
Had I a thousand lives, I'd give 'em all,
Before I would draw one tear more from that virtue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be not too cruel sir, and yet his bold sword —
But his life cannot restore that he's a man too —
Of a fair promise, but alas my sons dead;
If I have justice, must it kill him?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: If I have not, it kills me, strong and goodly!
Why should he perish too?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It lies in your power,
You only may accuse him, or may quit him.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be there no other witnesses?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Not any.
And if I save him, will not the world proclaim,
I have forgotten a son, to save a murderer?
And yet he looks not like one, he looks manly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pity so brave a gentleman should perish.
She cannot be so hard, so cruel hearted.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Will you pronounce? yet stay a little sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Rid yourself lady, of this misery;
And let me go, I do but breed more tempests,
With which you are already, to much shaken.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Do now, pronounce; I will not hear.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You shall not,
Yet turn and see good madam.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Do not wonder.
'Tis he, restored again, thank the good doctor,
Pray do not stand amazed, it is Duarte;
Is well, is safe again.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O my sweet son.
I will not press my wonder now with questions —
Sir, I am sorry for that cruelty,
I urged against you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Madam it was but justice.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: 'Tis true, the doctor healed this body again,
But this man healed my soul, made my mind perfect,
The good sharp lessons his sword read to me, saved me;
For which, if you loved me dear mother,
Honour and love this man.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You sent this letter,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My boldness makes me blush now.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I'll wipe of that,
And with this kiss, I take you for my husband,
Your wooings done sir; I believe you love me,
And that's the wealth I look for now.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have it.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You have ended my desire to all my wishes.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now 'tis a wedding again. And if Hypollita,
Make good, what with the hazard of her life,
She undertook, the evening will set clear.
sp.stage: Enter. Hypollita. leading Leopold. Arnoldo. Zenocia. in either hand. Zabulon. Sulpitia.
sp.l: After a stormy day.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Here comes the lady.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: With fair Zenocia,
Health with life again,
Restored unto her.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: The gift of her goodness.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let us embrace, I am of your order too,
And though I once despaired of women, now,
I find they relish much of scorpions,
For both have stings, and both can hurt, and cure too;
But what have been your fortunes?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: We'll defer
Our story, and at time more fit, relate it.
Now all that reverence virtue, and in that
Zenocia's constancy, and perfect love,
Or for her sake Arnoldo, join with us
In th' honour of this lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She deserves it.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Hippolyta's life, shall make that good hereafter,
Nor will I alone, better myself but others:
For these whose wants perhaps, have made their actions
Not altogether innocent, shall from me
Be so supplied; that need should not compel them,
To any course of life, but what the law
Shall give allowance to.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Sulp. Your ladyships creatures.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Be so and no more, you man-huckster.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: And worthy Leopold, you that with such fervour,
So long have sought me, and in that deserved me,
Shall now find full reward, for all your travels,
Which you have made more dear, by patient sufferance.
And though my violent dotage did transport me,
Beyond those bounds, my modesty should have kept in,
Though my desires were loose, from unchaste art,
Heaven knows I am free.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: The thought of that's dead to me;
I gladly take your offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do so sir,
A piece of cracked gold, ever will weigh down
Silver that's whole.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You shall be all my guests,
I must not be denied.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Come my Zenocia.
Our bark at length has found a quiet harbour;
And the unspotted progress of our loves
Ends not alone in safety but reward,
To instruct others, by our fair example;
That though good purposes, are long withstood,
The hand of heaven still guides such as are good.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: So free this work is, gentlemen, from offence,
That we are confident, it needs no defence
From us, or from the poets — we dare look.
On any man, that brings his table-book
To write down, what again he may repeat
At some great table, to deserve his meat.
Let such come swollen with malice, to apply
What it mirth here, there for an injury.
Nor lord, nor lady we have taxed; nor state,
Nor any private person, their poor hate
Will be starved here, for envy shall not find,
One touch that may be wrested to her mind.
And yet despair not gentlemen, the play
Is quick and witty; so the poets say,
And we believe them; the plot neat, and new,
Fashioned like those, that are approved by you.
Only 'twill crave attention, in the most;
Because one point unmarked, the whole is lost
Hear first than, and judge after, and be free,
And as our cause is, let our censure be.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Why there should be an epilogue to a play.
I know no cause, the old and usual way,
For which they were made, was to entreat the grace
Of such as were spectators in this place,
And time, 'tis to no purpose; for I know
What you resolve already to bestow,
Will not be altered, whatsoe'er I say,
In the behalf of us, and of the play:
Only to quit our doubts, if you think fit,
You may, or cry it up; or silence it.

div.head: Another prologue for the custom of the country. For my son clerk.
div.l: We wish, if it were possible, you knew
What we would give for this nights look, if new?
It being our ambition to delight
Our kind spectators with what's good, and right.
Yet so far know, and credit me, 'twas made
By such, as were held workmen in their trade,
At a time too, when they as I divine,
Were truly merry, and drank lusty wine.
The nectar of the Muses; some are here
I dare presume, to whom it did appear.
A well-drawn piece, which gave a lawful birth
To passionate scenes mixed with no vulgar mirth.
But unto such to whom 'tis known by fame
From others, perhaps only by the name.
I am a suitor, that they would prepare
Sound palates, and then judge their bill of fare.
It were injustice to decry this now
For being liked before, you may allow
(Your candour safe) what's taught in the old schools,
All such as lived before you, were not fools.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: I spoke much in the prologue for the play,
To its desert I hope, yet you might say
Should I change now from that, which then was meant,
Or in a syllable grow less confident.
I were weakhearted. I am still the same
In my opinion, and forbear to frame
Qualification, or excuse: if you
Concur with me, and hold my judgement true.
Show it with any sign, and from this place,
Or send me off exploded, or with grace.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
